homepage_content: The Sherman Historical Society - Home The Sherman Historical Society Home About the Society, Northrop House Museum and the RSLC Old Store Gift Shop & Museum Support the Society: Membership/Donations/ Memorials eNewsletters / Programs / Events / Scholarships Volunteer / Contact Us / Email Sign-Up 10 Route 37 Center Sherman, Connecticut 06784 860-354-3083 office@shermanhistoricalsociety.org We attempt to update our website regularly, but for the most up-to-date information, please follow us on Facebook or sign up for our e-news blasts. Send your email to us! WE Celebrated with Shots heard 'round the center! ( The Sherman Historical Society’s 50th anniversary reenactment was a blast!!! (Literally, with both cannon and musket fire!) We had the perfect weather and the event was a rousing success! It was our way to celebrate and thank the community for our longevity and you showed us such appreciation with your attendance! What an outpouring of interest and support! The reenactors and colonial villagers truly brought history to life, interacting with visitors, demonstrating and answering questions about what life was like in colonial times as a community and as a young country at war for its independence. What were battles like? How did troops communicate? Who spied on whom and how? How were injuries treated? How was food preserved? How were shoes and garments and household goods made? It was a thoroughly immersive experience all around. The day opened with welcome by Society President Elizabeth M. Haney, (whose leadership orchestrated this entire event) followed by the reading of a town proclamation by First Selectman Don Lowe, and a rousing speech by founding father Roger Sherman (embodied by actor Charles Roth). This event was nearly a year in the preparation and would not have been made possible without the support of so, so very many. We wish to thank them all wholeheartedly: from all the reenactors—5th Connecticut Regiment, Ye Olde Lebanon Towne Militia Co., and the 38th (1st Staffordshire) Regiment of Foot—and colonial artisans, to our event photographers John and Masumi O'Donnell, our Scout Troop 48 food vendor, our costumer suppliers, our audio tech, our firewood fillers, and our cannon contributor. We could not have coordinated this without the phenomenal cooperation of the Town of Sherman: First Selectman Don Lowe, Park and Rec, Kris Fazzone and the Department of Emergency Services, Town Maintenance, NCLC, our parking team led by Bob Ostrosky, plus those who stepped in last minute to direct traffic, and Dave, our Shuttle driver. To the Society volunteers who cleaned up, cleaned out, built, set up—and pulled off a variety of feats to organize and stage our event. We held a "Tavern Night" thank you for our reenactors and sponsors and it was spearheaded by Society Volunteer Allyson M. Mard, catered by Blue on Bank (New Milford), and the audience enjoyed colonial tunes provided by talented musician and singer Jeff Butler. Of course, this would not have been possible without the understanding of the center residents as well, who put up with the noise and traffic, and offered Volunteer parking. Our neighbors, who allowed us the use of their beautiful field for the start of our skirmish (the perfect backdrop!). And last but certainly not least: our generous sponsors: the Great Circle Foundation for their grant, our “Patriot Level” sponsors: Beatty Construction Company, Club River Oaks, and Superior Spring & Manufacturing Co. Inc. We thank our additional sponsors as well: Steve Thorne (to honor past president Gloria Thorne), Lori Finck, UBS, Jennings Oil & Propane, Collins-Morrow Insurance, Inc., Hair by Suzi, and Norbert E. Mitchell, Co. Inc. We couldn't have done it without your partnership! Thank you for celebrating with us! We are 50 years old and 50 years young! Here’s to continuing to preserve and present Sherman’s History. Pictured above: British Troops advance during the afternoon skirmish. Below, Society President Elizabeth M. Haney addresses the assembly, flanked by First Selectman Don Lowe and Patriot Troops from the 5th Connecticut Regiment. "As President of the Sherman Historical Society, what excites me most from this tremendously successful reenactment, is seeing history come alive for our community. The day brought together neighbors, friends, students, families, and visitors who were able to step back into 1775 and truly experience the sights, sounds and spirit of our town's past. I'm especially proud of how many Sherman organizations, sponsors, volunteers, and participants joined forces with the SHS to make this event not just a reenactment, but a shared celebration of our heritage." —Elizabeth M. Haney We'll finish off our 50th with our Holiday Open House & Barn event in December. Decorations, desserts, open hearth cooking, good friends and good cheer! Then we look ahead to C elebrating our Nation's 250th in 2026 with focus on founding father Roger Sherman, and a concert of period music. Stay tuned for more! Come join us as we celebrate 50, 250 and beyond! Annual Meeting, September 25, 2025 The annual meeting of the membership was held at Northrop House, Thursday, September 25, 2025 at 7pm. It was a brief meeting with reports from the President and other officers of the Board. At this meeting, three new board members were elected: Alan Braverman , Bernadette Linero , and Richard Lenihan . We welcome them and the new energy they bring to the Board. Also recognized—due & overdue—our volunteers of the year(s): For 2023/24, HelenAnne Ostrosky and for 2024/25: Dick Haney (pictured at right.) HelenAnne has been a longtime member of the Society and the Board who brings high energy and commitment to all she does and she does so very much! Dick, whose last name you'll recognize, humbly says he was "conscripted by marriage" to the Society president, but he has stepped up as a stalwart volunteer in every sense and for every event and program that the Society has held for the last several years. Muscle, heart and brains fit both our honorees and we appreciate them! For more on each. If anyone would like a copy of the annual report, please email the Soci ety. NEW BOOK RELEASE! ​Local in-depth researcher/author John Cilio and font of Sherman knowledge, Ann Price, have collaborated on Lake Mauweehoo History , a meticulously detailed, enlightening tale of this community's beginnings. The book is filled with wonderful vintage photographs. A must-have for any Sherman history buff. A BOOK TALK and Signing by John and Ann will be held at the Sherman Library on Thursday, July 24, 2025, at 7pm . Click here for more . Copies are available at The Old Store. 2025 Gloria Thorne Scholarship The Society awarded its 202 5 $5000 Gloria Thorne Scholarship to Alexander Ostrosky , a graduate of Shepaug Valley High School, who has volunteered with the Society for many years. He has helped with Barn Sale, cleaning and organizing, as well as after-school programs and summer camp. He is a thoughtful young man, whose passions are math and science. He excelled academically and hopes to study stem-related curriculum at The University of Scranton. We are proud of his many accomplishments, and appreciate the hours he dedicated to volunteering. We wish him well! 2025-2026 MEMBERSHIP DRIVE Without you, We'd be History. With You, We Thrive and Keep History ALIVE. Since 1975, The Society has preserved and interpreted our history for residents as well as for visitors to our beautiful town. We are only able to do this thanks to our members. You allow our mission to be a reality. As always we thank you for your generosity and continued support! As we look back on the past year, we are truly grateful for the generosity of so many donors who kept our mission alive, for the many volunteers who made this year's Barn Sale a success, and who helped with programs for young and old, and for all of you who participated in our events. We would not be here without you. On behalf of the Board of Directors, we would like to again thank you for Keeping History Alive in the Present, and for the Future. Our annual newsletter was sent out town-wide in August and to members near and far. It included a remittance envelope, or you can join via the link below. PLEASE CONSIDER BECOMING A MEMBER or RENEWING! You can mail a check to the office or select your Level of membership from the drop down box and click "Join Now" to make your dues payment via PayPal. Please click here for more information on how to donate. ​ Also, if you did not get our Annual Newsletter in the mail, please click here for your copy. Levels Household/Family $30.00 USD Sponsor $50.00 USD Patron $100.00 USD Benefactor $250.00 USD Life $500.00 USD Corporate $1,000.00 USD Other $0.00 USD THE OLD STORE MUSEUM​ & GIFT SHOP If you have been shopping at The Old Store Museum & Gift Shop, you know it’s more than a reminder of bygone days, it is not just a mere shop; it’s a bastion of history, a gathering place and a testament to the town’s resilient spirit. It’s a place where neighbors become friends and strangers become familiar faces. In an era where digital interactions often take precedence, the old-fashioned charm of The Old Store reminds us of the value of human connections forged over a wooden countertop. Your patronage, year after year, plays a vital role in keeping The Old Store Museum & Gift Shop operational, much like a lifeblood pumping through the veins of a cherished community landmark. The Old Store Museum is a living museum, where the walls whisper tales of past generations and the creaky floorboards groan with the weight of time. By choosing to shop with us, staffed 100% by volunteers, locals and visitors alike contribute to the maintenance of a tangible piece of the town’s heritage. Each purchase made is a vote for the continuation of this legacy, allowing the store to remain a beacon of Sherman’s storied past amidst the ever-evolving present. The mission of The Old Store Gift Shop is to be self-sufficient, pay all of its expenses while maintaining the over 200-year-old building and provide funds for the SHS endowment as well as programs for SHS as needed. Your purchases helped us replace a section of The Old Store’s roof and will help toward adding air-conditioning to our second floor where we now house a wonderful exhibit. Each transaction is a declaration of support for a way of life that values authenticity, relationships, and the rich tapestry of our heritage. Come see us, shop for the gift you need (we get new items every week) and we might have just the right gift. And we wrap for no charge. Remember, we “have a little of a lot,” we change with the seasons and the holidays are fast approaching!! ​ NEW BOOK: Lake Mauweehoo History by John Cilio and Ann Price is available for purchase. BOOK RE-RELEASED. We are pleased to reprint the late James Lincoln Collier’s earlier publication, The Bohemians of Robber Rocks , in which he provides an insightful look back at our local history, from colonial times to the colorful 1930s—when a menagerie of Bohemian writers, artists, and actors of note took up residence at the seventeenth century homestead, Robber Rocks , that lies on the Pawling/Sherman border. It is a personal retelling that complements our 2022 book, Reflections, that is filled with personal stories of locals from that era, from the quiet dignity of Edna Barnes to the wild antics of the Bohemians. Both books are available at The Old Store, $30 each. The Old Store Museum & Gift Shop is located at 3 Route 37 Center in Sherman. Our hours are Friday through Sunday from 12 to 4. Hope to see you soon! TO CONTACT US: 860-350-3475 or email 2024 EXHIBIT: "MEMORIES OF THE GENERAL STORE" The Society has mounted a three-location exhibit to celebrate over 100 years of the General Store (and its many lives) in Sherman. The main display in Northrop House, which features a variety of stores once in the area, is open Sat. and Sun. 1-3. The Old Store houses all the items left to the Society from what was Lester Bennett’s IGA as well as many vintage photos. The Old Store is open Fri. through Sun. 12-4. The third part is a display at the current GA, on the shelf over the meat counter. Have a look next time you shop! The Society was pleased to add to this exhibit, a section to mark Mike Luzi’s 41st year owning the current IGA and his dedication to our town. We encourage you to visit all the exhibits, which run through October Click here for a video of Mike Luzi's visit to the exhibit. MEET OUR NEW BOARD MEMBERS At our Annual Meeting in September, we elected three additional Board Members to our governing team: Renée Collins, Lucy Seda and Helen Anne Ostrosky . They each bring unique talents and energy to the table. (Please see page 8 for a full list of our Board.) Renée Collins has called Sherman home for the past four decades. Currently, she is a dedicated volunteer at The Old Store. She raised two children here and has proudly served as a realtor helping families find their dream homes and invest in the beauty of this town. Lucy Seda, her husband and two teens have taken delight in Sherman since their move in 2018. Lucy works in the healthcare field. She believes, however, her best work has taken place through volunteerism. Helen Anne Ostrosky has lived in Sherman since 1999, and has raised four children here. She currently works as an Assistant Preschool Teacher at Christ Church Preschool in Pawling NY. Helen Anne began volunteering at SHS with Membership and Kids@Cobbler Shop programs. She teamed up to start the Hooked on History children’s programs. She looks forward to collaborating with the current and past board members and volunteers! PROGRAMS, EVENTS, AND MORE HAPPENINGS AROUND THE SHS We still have much to do to get back to our programs, including volunteers to help us run them. If you are inter-ested, contact us. This past year, SHS co-sponsored with the Sherman Library, John Cilio’s informative talk on Taverns and their role in colonial life in New England, and highlighted those right here in Sherman. Did you know the library sits on the land once occupied by Fuller’s Tavern? We hope to sponsor more of these talks. Our annual Holiday Open House took place on December 2nd, 3rd, and 9th, 2023, featuring a special visit from Santa, who joined us for the community Christmas Tree and Menorah lighting. Our theme, “A Stroll Down Memory Lane,” offered a festive and nostalgic way to welcome the community and express our heartfelt thanks for your continued support of our volunteer organization. It was a wonderful way to usher in the holiday season, and we hope you enjoyed it as much as we did. We’re already planning this year’s theme and look forward to creating another memorable experience for you! Our Annual Fundraising Barn Sale was a tremendous success, and we extend our deepest thanks to everyone who made it possible. From the generous donations we received to the enthusiastic buyers who turned out in droves, your support was invaluable. We’re especially grateful to the dedicated volunteers who worked tirelessly for weeks to prepare, setting up and taking down the tent, organizing the sale, and ensuring everything ran smoothly. Thanks to effective publicity, the word got out—and you all made it a success. Even the weather was perfect! One loyal customer in line confessed, “This is my favorite day of the year. Not my birthday, not Christmas, but your annual barn sale. No matter where I am, I’d take the red-eye back just to be here.” How can we not feel the love? In addition, SHS hosted Sherman School’s 2nd Grade visit and the 4th & 5th Grade’s Colonial Days event. We look forward to hosting more educational events to inspire and enlighten our community in addition to our historic 50th anniversary planning, which just might prove to be—Revolutionary! If you have an historic collection or are interested in presenting a history lecture or workshop, let us know . NOrthrop House gets some pampering The Northrop House Museum was closed for a good while this past year to make necessary repairs and upgrades. These were made possible by a generous grant from the Ada Howe Kent Foundation. The water damage to the ceiling in the upstairs bedroom w as repaired, the room repainted and the floors refinished. After Holiday Open House, the exhibit room and parlor were emptied of furniture so that both rooms could be repainted. We then added the bathroom into the mix where both repairs and painting were warranted. Railings were installed to the attic, as was much-needed lighting. Office lighting was repaired and both exhibit room and basement were made brighter with upgraded fixtures. It was a huge undertaking and we appreciate all who lent their skills to the job: Bill & Ken from Linke’s Painting; Mike Koraus Plumbing; Todd Russell for the electrical; and Jan Desiato for his overseeing the work and making the much needed carpentry repairs. We'll be thanking more folks next newsletter as we continue to get ourselves back into shape! Image Credit: Marie Loria Did You Know... The NEW Roger Sherman Learning Center This rendering was done by our local graphic designer, Marie Loria, who, incidentally lives with her family on the property that was, 275 years ago, the Roger Sherman farm. It is a time line display which shows the trades that Roger Sherman mastered and the contributions he made in his public life. The cabinet surrounding the time line has now been completed by Jan Desiato. This time line display is the centerpiece of our Roger Sherman Learning Center. Accompanying the time line is a downloadable audio that adds a wealth of detail about Roger Sherman's life, his family, the places where he lived and a sampling of documents and artifacts related to his life. The display is open to the public by appointment only, it is accompanied by period furnishings, all with connections to residents of Sherman, photographs of early and contemporary Sherman Residents and descendants of Roger Sherman. It has a computer based research center which contains our growing collection of Sherman's documents (transcribed for readability), local oral histories and the barns of Sherman, all of which have been photographed. The center space is used for educational purposes for Sherman School students, public programs and special exhibits. Photo Credit: Yale University Art Gallery Did You Know... Roger Sherman...'The Forgotten Founding Father.' By John Jenner It has been noted by Roger Sherman's biographers that he is "The Forgotten Founding Father". If we knew what he had contributed to the founding of our nation we would think of him as the Great Connecticut Statesman, our most important revolutionary hero. What did he contribute? He served in the Continental Congress from its first meeting in 1774, through the Revolutionary War. Washington fought the war. but the Continental Congress ran the war and provided the weaponry, food, uniforms and finance. Roger Sherman was the only founder to sign all four of the founding documents and he played a significant roll in each of them. The first was the "Articles of Association". The thirteen colonies had many border disputes that had to be resolved before colonies could unite to declare their independence as a committed set of thirteen states. Perhaps the greatest border dispute was the CT grant that extended westward across the upper half of Pennsylvania to Lake Erie. CT gave up these rights, holding only their portion of what is now Ohio. This is the Western Reserve, where CT citizen were given opportunities after the war. Our second founding document was "The Declaration of Independence" . We generally attribute it to Thomas Jefferson but, in fact, it was a committee of five statesmen who created it. They were: Jefferson; John Adams; Benjamin Franklin; Robert Livingston and Roger Sherman. If you still have a two dollar bill tucked away and look on the back you’ll find a copy of the painting by our own John Trumball depicting the committee presenting the draft to John Hancock. Our constitution is not the first one under which we were governed as a nation after the Revolutionary War. The first was "The Articles of Confederation", and there were thirteen Heads of State before Washington. It did not work well because the balance of power between the states and the central government had not been properly crafted. Concerned leaders convinced Washington to convene the Constitutional Convention to draft a new constitution. The states representatives were deadlocked over the states vs. federal balance as before until Roger Sherman again proposed "The Great Compromise", which provides for proportional representation in the House and equal representation in the Senate. The deadlock was resolved, the "U.S. Constitution" was drafted, signed and taken back to the states for ratification. CT, under Roger Sherman's leadership, was the second state to ratify our constitution. When George Washington was elected first President under our present constitution and the first Congress was seated, Roger Sherman was a CT Representative in the House. After a year or so one of our CT Senators resigned and Roger Sherman was selected to take his seat in the Senate, where he served until his death. Your may recall that James Madison is credited with drafting the first ten amendments to our constitution, which we call "The Bill of Rights". A few years ago a draft copy of Madison's proposed nine rights was discovered in the National Archives among the Madison papers. It had Roger Sherman's comments and a suggested tenth right. Wouldn't you like to know which one he proposed? Doesn't it seem to you that Roger Sherman should be recognized as one of our Founding Fathers? He served in public office almost fifty years and that is longer than any of our other recognized Founding Fathers. Our Mission To bring together people interested in Sherman's history, to collect and preserve objects which help to establish or illustrate its history, to acquire and manage any property available to the Society, to interest young people in their town's heritage, to publish historical information, and to maintain a library of historical materials. name: Camp Bartow Historic Site
address: Old Pike Rd, Arbovale, WV 24915, USA
homepage_content: Camp Bartow - WV Land Trust Skip to content Camp Bartow Bird Watching Hiking Historical Site Protected In the fall of 2016, WVLT purchased a historic Civil War site in Pocahontas County, known as Camp Bartow. The property was the scene of the Battle of Greenbrier River in October 1861. The 14-acre property lies in the heart of the battlefield and was a campground of the 31st Virginia Infantry. As part of the first campaign of the Civil War, the battle proved instrumental in the creation of West Virginia in 1863. Location & Access Google Maps GPS (Or type “Yeager House, Bartow, WV” in your GPS. The Yeager House is across the street.) Driving directions: From I-79, take exit 99 (Weston) Turn onto Rt-119 N / Rt-33 (travel 14.5 miles) Keep left to continue on Rt-33 E / Rt 48 E (travel 19.6 miles) Slight right onto WV-92 S (travel 45.3 miles) Turn left onto Old Pike Road and Camp Bartow will be on your right! Yeager House Lodging On October 5, 2019 a ribbon was cut, a “six-pounder” cannon was fired, and Camp Bartow was officially opened to the public! Many thanks to the WV Humanities Council for funding this site interpretation! Newsletter Signup

Discover Putnam VA Retirement, Compensation and Healthcare Many Veterans don't know the difference between Retirement Pay, and Compensation Pay. You may be entitled to BOTH, and one is Tax Free. Talk to our Veteran Service Officer to see if you can get more money (That you DESERVE), or get free healthcare. Some of these options extend to your Family! MORE INFO Previous Next WELCOME TO PUTNAM Putnam VFW 1523: United in Service, Committed to Support Putnam Connecticut As yesterday's defenders of freedom, we want to welcome today's military service members into our ranks to become part of our elite group. Our common bond is the battlefield, whether it is service in the Persian Gulf, Korea, Kosovo, the war on terrorism or peace-keeping expeditionary campaigns. Your courage and sacrifice have made a difference in preserving and defending world peace. Commander's Message: We are here for you. Without you, we have no purpose, and that is the silent killer of today's Veterans. Let us help you. Our Post is made up of not just the Veterans who deployed to Conflict Zones, but also the VFW Auxiliary, which is the Family of those who have deployed to conflict zones. Their support of our programs and activities makes our mission all the more important. The members of the Auxiliary know what it's like to be a Family member to a Service Member and the unique benefits and conflicts that come with being a family member. Be sure to check out the Auxiliary's "About" section if you are a Family Member of a combat deployed Veteran. Lastly, the Putnam VFW has the unique pleasure of working with the local Friends of VFW Post 1523, who are just Community Members that are dedicated to assisting us with our missions here at the Post! MORE Commander's Corner Commander Hans Lowell Welcome to Albert J. Breault VFW Post 1523! As the Commander of this esteemed post, I am honored to extend a warm welcome to all our members, veterans, and community supporters. Our mission is to provide a supportive environment where veterans can find camaraderie, purpose, and the assistance they need. The Canteen: A Place to Relax and Connect Our Canteen is the hub of our post, offering a welcoming space for veterans to relax and connect with their brothers and sisters in arms. Here, you can enjoy inexpensive drinks, engage in friendly conversations, and meet local clientele who share a deep respect for our veterans. The Canteen is more than just a place to unwind; itâs a hub of camaraderie that boosts morale and fosters a sense of belonging. The Post Hall: A Hub for Community Events Our Post Hall is a versatile space that hosts a variety of incredible community events and dinners, all aimed at raising funds for veterans and the community. From festive dinners to charity events, our hall is the perfect venue for creating memorable experiences. These events not only provide essential support to our post and its members but also strengthen our bond with the community. We invite you to join us at these gatherings and witness firsthand the positive impact we can achieve together. What We Stand For At Albert J. Breault VFW Post 1523, we are dedicated to serving our veterans and the community through various initiatives: Veteran Services Assistance : We provide support to veterans in accessing the benefits they rightfully earned. Patriotic Education : We promote patriotism and educate the community about the sacrifices made by our service members. Volunteers : Our post is powered by the dedication of veterans, family members, and community volunteers who go above and beyond to help out. Camaraderie : We offer a sense of purpose and connection for veterans, ensuring they feel valued and supported. Community Outreach and Youth Involvement : We actively engage with the community and involve youth in our programs to foster a spirit of service and patriotism. Chaplain Services : We provide spiritual support and guidance to our members. Large Membership Group : With over 170+ members, our post is a vibrant and active community. Direct Link to the Community : We strive to assist the community wherever possible, creating a strong bond between veterans and local residents. A Final Message Albert J. Breault VFW Post 1523 is committed to making a positive impact through continued involvement from veterans and the community. Together, we can support those in need, foster a sense of belonging, and enhance the well-being of our members and the community at large. Your participation and support are crucial to our mission, and we look forward to achieving great things together. Thank you for being a part of our community and for your unwavering commitment to our veterans. Hans Lowell Commander VFW Post 1523 cmd@vfw1523.org FACEBOOK FEED Come back frequently to see all the happenings and goings on at . We pride ourselves with our commitment to the community and veterans. Scroll through our feed to see our most recent posts. OUR FACEBOOK PAGE OUR MISSION A Post for the Veterans and their Families of the Putnam CT area. A place of like-minded Veterans to relax and/or give back to the Putnam Community and the surrounding towns. We strive to ensure Domestic Tranquility, promote the General Welfare, and Secure the Blessings of Liberty that we fought for, for our selves, our families and our neighbors. If we don't do this, what were we doing when we served? name: Bellamy-Ferriday House & Garden
address: 9 Main St N, Bethlehem, CT 06751, USA
homepage_content: Bellamy-Ferriday House & Garden – Connecticut Landmarks Skip to content Loading... Bellamy-Ferriday House & Garden Pete Hary 2025-10-22T12:38:12-04:00 Bellamy-Ferriday House & Garden 9 Main Street North, Bethlehem, CT 06751 bellamy.ferriday@ctlandmarks.org • (203) 266-7596 Purchase Tickets PROGRAMS & EVENTS PRIVATE GROUP TOURS Hours Open for tours May through October May–June: Wednesday–Sunday, 12 noon–4 pm July–September: Thursday–Sunday, 12 noon–4 pm October: Saturday and Sunday, 12 noon–4 pm Tours every half hour; last tour departs 30 minutes before closing. For groups larger than 10 people, please call 203-266-7596 or email bellamy.ferriday@ctlandmarks.org to plan your visit. Learn more about group tours » Admission House Tour $16 / Adult $12 / Senior, Student, or Teacher $5 / Child 6-18 Free for Connecticut Landmarks Members & Children under 6 Grounds Pass* $7 / Person Free for Connecticut Landmarks Members *House Tour includes access to Gardens & Grounds. For Gardens & Grounds pass ONLY, please select the appropriate ticket type below. House Tour Explore the life of Caroline Ferriday, a 20th-century philanthropist who championed human rights and social justice causes. Her work took her around the globe, aiding victims of Ravensbrück concentration camp and supporting the Civil Rights Movement in the United States. A visit to the ten-acre site includes the grounds, a formal parterre garden, and the 18th century residence built by Reverend Joseph Bellamy. Visitors will discuss the ways that beliefs and values can guide one’s actions by interpreting the lives, actions, and commitments of the house’s former residents. Upcoming Tours Programs & Events LEARN MORE Help us plant seeds for the future by sponsoring a zinnia plant today! The Bellamy-Ferriday House & Garden started its life as the Bellamy Manse, built by Reverend Joseph Bellamy. A preacher of great renown, Bellamy traveled throughout New England preaching the message of the First Great Awakening. His writings were published in New York, Boston, and Scotland. He built the house in two stages, beginning in 1754 and finishing in 1767 as his family, theological seminary, and stature grew. The property increased to 100 acres and was owned by his family for a century. In 1912, New Yorkers Henry and Eliza Ferriday purchased the property as a summer residence for themselves and their only child Caroline. Beginning when she was 9 years old, Caroline Ferriday spent 78 summers on the property. The Ferriday family updated the house with modern amenities such as heat, electricity, and plumbing. Eliza and Caroline designed a formal parterre garden which features historic roses, peonies, lilacs, and numerous fragrant trees and shrubs. Interested in the life of Bellamy, Caroline researched and collected antiques related to Reverend Bellamy’s life, many of which are still on display in the house. Caroline Ferriday supported many social justice and human rights causes. In particular, she supported the Free France Movement during World War II and secured medical assistance for survivors of Ravensbrück concentration camp. These survivors, many of which were horribly disfigured, were able to start their lives again thanks to the philanthropy of Caroline Ferriday. She received the Cross of Lorraine and the French Legion of Honor medal for her efforts. A fictionalized account of Caroline’s life, focusing on her work with the women of Ravensbrück, is chronicled in the New York Times best-selling book Lilac Girls by Martha Hall Kelly. Kelly also wrote two more historic-fiction novels, Lost Roses and Sunflower Sisters which tell stories of Eliza Ferriday and the Woolsey Sisters, respectively. Page load link Go to Top

name: Edward Waldo House
address: 96 Waldo Rd, Baltic, CT 06330, USA
homepage_content: Town of Scotland Connecticut Historical Society The waldo House Introduction Prologue History Gennie's Tour The House Survives The Tour Today Kin Keeper Postscript Introduction Henry Bowers - Our Old Homestead "If you will come with me, we will walk down the lane and pay a visit to the old house. Looking up, we see a plain brown house, built square, and two stories high with a great stone chimney at the top. Shall we go up the step and knock at the door? It would be useless, they would not hear us for the dear old house, built by my grandfather’s grandfather nearly two hundred years ago is at last deserted. Yet happy memories of the happy days spent under its hospitable roof come often to those who once knew and loved it as home and to whom it is still dear." Gennie Waldo 1871 Edward Waldo House Prologue Genevieve Waldo was seventeen when she wrote this bittersweet reflection about the Waldo House, the homestead her ancestors had built in 1715. Her bachelor uncle had died leaving the house empty. She had grown up in the old house with her parents and doting elderly aunt and uncle but now lived “down the lane” in a house her father, George, had built in 1857. It was a sad time in this house. Gennie had heard her parents talk about leaving Waldo Valley and moving to her mother’s family house on Long Island. The Sprague Manufacturing Company, owner of the world’s largest textile mill, five miles down the Shetucket River, was threatening to raise its dam and flood their fields. The company even planned to build another, maybe even two, enormous mills just one half mile up the river. Sprague had already bought nearby property from another Waldo cousin and although Gennie’s father had never entertained the mill’s offer to buy their house, he seemed resigned to the inevitable. George Waldo House 1857 Twenty years earlier, Waldos had fought the mill owners’ first expansion into their countryside. They had fought Sprague’s railroad taking by eminent domain a one and one-half mile right of way through the middle of their farmlands and they lost. They then had fought the mill’s water rights privileges to flood their farmlands and they lost. Later, they had won in court a small compensation against the mill after it had torn down one of the family’s most important possessions, its sawmill. But these new encroachments were just too much, too big, they would have to leave their grandfather’s grandfather’s land. Gennie’s world seemed to be coming to an end in another more poignant way. The youngest of this family’s children had recently died in infancy. Gennie’s grief stricken mother was gone to recuperate for long periods of time leaving Gennie, the eldest daughter, to raise with her spinster aunt her five siblings who ranged in age from 7 to 15. Although her father’s transcendental religion saved him from a sense of despair, it could not save him from the mysterious disease that bound him to a wheel chair. History Gennie's Family Even knowing all these troubles, Gennie could not understand why her parents were considering abandoning the house and Waldo Valley. She was proud of her family’s past and of the house that had always been theirs. Everything seemed so permanent. After all, the house wasn’t just old, it was ancient. Inside the attic’s trunks, there were deeds, inventories, account books that told the story of their search for land, starting with Cornelius’, the Waldo patriarch, migration from England to the New World in 1643. Cornelius’ son, John and his wife, Rebecca Adams, were among the early English settlers from the colonial towns on Massachusetts Bay, in the wake of King Phillip’s War of 1675 -1677, to permanently settle and farm the area. They arrived in time to take part in a fury of real estate transactions just twenty years after the Mohegan Sachem Joshua, son of Uncas, bequeathed to the “sixteen gentlemen of Norwich the Eight Miles Broad”. This Sachem’s generosity left his children so destitute that his son, Abimelech, was forced to sell his remaining land, 10,000 acres called Mamasqueeg. Gennie knew of a few remaining, “squatting” royal Mohegans high in the hills surrounding her valley but they were “poor Indians”, too poor to claim anyone’s land. A century after Cornelius’ arrival, his family was flourishing. The average mid-1700s farm was 40 acres and a large farm had 70. But with hard work with large powerful hands, sound farming practices, and a few good real estate deals, Edward was able to expand his farm to over 500 acres. But this good fortune was now changing. As Gennie held these ancient fragile documents of ownership, she realized that what had happened to the Native Americans could happen to her family. Edward Waldo Deed 1705 The old leather, sheep skinned trunks held together with diamond headed nails also held the precious memories of her ancestors’ lives. Neatly stacked in rows were hundreds of their letters. Among them was a sorrowful letter from her great aunt Eunice in Illinois detailing her husband’s early death and pleading to come home with her six children. Congregational minister, Daniel Waldo, sent evangelical letters describing his fights with the Baptists and efforts to convert the Indians in New York. Like Eunice, Daniel wrote of the terrible deaths due to epidemics and expressed faith that salvation was certain for those who “die in the Lord”. Her Uncle Giles’ letters describe his voyages to the South Seas searching for fame and then his return to the Gold Rush desperate for fortune. They all begged for news about the family and the homestead, knowing they would not hear back for months. Gennie was also worried that if the house slipped out of Waldo hands, future descendants would forget about them and their other accomplishments. She had been told, for example, of her grandfather’s grandfather’s contributions to the early colony, his appointment as a lieutenant in the town’s militia for his Majesty’s (King George) Service, in 1720 and his service as deputy for the town to the Connecticut General Assembly during the 1720s. She had heard how, a couple of generations later, her ancestors had overcome their English loyalties and ardently supported the Revolution. Her great grandfather, the Reverend Ebenezer Devotion, had preached against the tyranny of British rule, a cause for which her grandfather, the Esquire Ebenezer Devotion Jr., had agitated. The minister fought the British taxes at the pulpit and the Esquire joined the Sons of Liberty and supplied the Continental Army from his store. She had read the colorful Revolutionary War letters her four great Waldo uncles sent home describing some of their battles in this war. And then there was the most inspiring and improbable of all stories, the rise of Samuel Huntington, her great great uncle and also first cousin twice removed, (colonial genealogies were often complicated by multiple marriages of two families) from small town boy to patriot and signer of the Declaration of Independence. Huntington went on to be the first president of the breakaway colonies, leading the Continental Congress, and later became Governor of Connecticut. Waldo House Attic From the many probated inventories of her male ancestors (colonial women could not own property) , Gennie could trace the growth of her families “wealth”. Along with their land which was the most valuable asset, their livestock grew considerably from just an oxen, a horse, and a few sheep to 2 oxen, several horses, 50 cows, 60 1 year olds, and many sheep. Household furniture gentrified from simple banner back chairs to Windsors, from square to round tables to a high chest desk, one great chair, and several featherbeds all crafted by local artisan furniture makers. Clothing improved from an essential large coat to several formal velvet jackets and from an essential pair of boots to several pair of shoes with silver buckles. Gennie was not surprised that the books were mostly religious – The Great Bible, sermons, psalms, hymns, but also a dictionary, some literature, and many childrens’ books. Perhaps what was most significant to Gennie was what was not listed - these Waldos did not own slaves. Along with many of the other leading families of this colonial period, Gennie’s maternal great grandparents (Devotions) had a male slave to help with manual labor and a female slave to spin the wool and clean the house and her several great Waldo grandfather had a young slave girl in Boston but the Waldos of this Waldo House, these Separatists, evangelical Christians, who abandoned themselves to God and lived Christ’s Gospels one of which said that no man could own another. Gennie knew the profound effect that this peculiar institution had not only on the slaves but also on those who eventually fought for its abolition. Her grandparents had sent her father and uncle to very early abolitionist schools where they worked, lived, and studied with freed slaves in the early 1830ies. They became early members of the American Anti-Slavery Society in 1833. They sought immediate unequivocal emancipation. These ideas would have been considered radical by the vast majority of Americans at that time. Although Connecticut had over 3,000 slaves in 1776, it was one of the first states to emancipate their slaves in 1784 with the Gradual Emancipation Act. It stated that those children born into slavery after March 1 st , 1784 would be free by the time they turn 25. As a result, slavery in Connecticut was practiced until 1848 but it took a Civil War with over 700,000 dead to kill “slavery dead” throughout the country. Her father George believed deeply that “Jehovah would triumph and free his people”. Gennie's Tour As if anticipating her family’s final abandonment of their ancestral home, Gennie takes her imagined readers on a tour first describing the grounds surrounding the house. There is “a tiny rose bush struggling with vines and weeds, trying to tell us what it once was”. She then asks rhetorically, “who can be the owner to leave everything to such wild neglect”? She proceeds inside, starting in the parlor. “The Room seems musty and feels to have suddenly stepped back into a room of the last century….grandmother’s looking glass with its quilt frame hangs between the two South windows. The American Eagle with outspread wings rests upon the top, his once brilliant plumage sadly tarnished, and well it might be for when first he spread his golden wings at the top of that ancient mirror, our national bird was in his glorious youth. Poor bird is he tired, standing for more than seventy years with outspread wings? Does he not long to fold them now and sink to rest?” Her melancholy for the old house expands to despair for her entire country. The Civil War, which had ended six years earlier, seems to tarnish her family’s significant accomplishments during the colonial era and her father’s abolitionism. She points out, against the opposite wall, her “grandfather’s bookcase, a strange piece of old fashioned furniture, a table, a bureau, a bookcase and a writing desk combined”. Its books reflected the range of Waldo interests: histories, literature, sacred scriptures, Greek and Latin texts, school books, children’s stories and documents on the Revolution. Gennie underscores the peculiar frozen nature of the room by describing “the fine looking family portraits nearly life sized, standing floor to ceiling“ and then finally “the old silent mysterious clock not wound in years. What tales of other years it might tell if it only would?” Oddly, Gennie leaves out one detail on her tour; the oldest piece of furniture in the parlor, her grandfather’s grandfather’s Deacon Chair with the initials EW on the back of the crest. Edward had once removed and then returned this chair to his Congregational Church because of a spiritual crisis. As a Separatist during the First Great Awakening, he claimed the right to speak in meeting and to hear exhorters preach to him. Excommunicated by his church, he would eventually make confession and be reinstated. Edward’s apostasy and return to the fold reminded her too much of her own father’s spiritual battles. George had been swept up in the Second Great Awakening, struggled mightily with his faith, only to outgrow the exhorters, distain populist revival meetings and never return to the fold. He writes in his Journal: “I went to church and heard an orthodox parrot speak of exclamations and humdrum phrases which I have heard repeated over and over again ever since my father was a baby. I shall not do it again. My Sabbath shall hereafter be spent roaming the fields, talking with myself, with God, reading-writing- praising-praying silently. I will not murder myself for the sake of gratifying others.” 1843 Edward Waldo’s Deacon Chair After his brother, Giles, meet and corresponded for two years with Ralph Waldo Emerson, another distant relative, the brothers left behind stern Calvinism for the intuitive, individual, nature-worshiping path of Transcendentalism. Gennie didn’t mind that the locals thought of her as one of the godless Waldos because she felt fortunate to grow up in a family that believed that God was present in nature and people, particularly in children’s souls. She was revered as a child. Although she would have been responsible for helping her mother with the household chores and helping her father on the farm, her most important duty was to be herself. She was instructed well in her ABCs but always encouraged to think for herself. Her father taught her well about the godliness of her valley. He took her on many walks like this one described in his Journal: “Come and walk with me and see the white clover everywhere thick among the green grass, the river glistening through the maples, and the hill rising up beyond wonderful grassland and grain land and trees that have walked out there in their sleep and now stand dreaming over the valley. You hear the notes of the wood thrush – they are perpetual here – ringing clear and sweet from the depths of the woods into the deeps of life. (1857) They looked and thought deeply; the trees walked and dreamt and the birds spoke to their souls. They could hear the river breathing in the distance and feel the hills embracing them. They could hear the silences of the ages and feel the subtle magnetism in nature. Here they were no longer owners of the land, the land owned them. The House Survives The natural beauty of Waldo Valley that Gennie experienced as a child remains to this day. And the old Waldo house that Gennie was so worried about was saved. The Sprague Manufacturing Company, builder of the largest textile mill in the world, had become overextended with debt and collapsed in the Depression of 1873. The mill building itself would collapse a few years later after heavy rains swelled the Shetucket River to biblical levels and the dam that the company had raised failed and washed away part of this mill. And the house did not remain deserted much longer as Gennie’s younger brother, Gerald, would graduate from Cornell University, earning a B.Ag and farm both homesteads until the 1940’s. By that time, Connecticut farms were dying out due to the competition of large scale western farms. After all the gifts of land to successive generations, the farm was down to 200 acres consisting of 80 in pasture, 30 in hay, 20 in grains, 10 in fruit orchards and 60 in woodlands. A 1939 Waldo Farm Income Statement briefly states: expenses $4337.04 income $3190.51 loss $1146.53 due to more hens killed and lower egg prices. Gerald would be the last farmer. He was proud that he was still able to keep the farm, keep the land. He was born knowing who he was, his confidence rooted in the land. He walked the same paths that his ancestors had walked. He plowed the same fields his ancestors had worked 250 years earlier. Waldo Farm Barns Waldo House Painting Giles Waldo Genealogy 1834 The old house remained in the Waldo family till 1975 when Ruth, Gerald’s daughter and Gennie’s niece, bequeathed it with a small endowment to a state historical society “to preserve the dwelling house, to be known as the Edward Waldo House, as a landmark of historical value and interest and employed solely for educational, benevolent, scenic and other philanthropic purposes”. But once again the survival of the house along with its contents became doubtful. This historical society with its patrician directors and its powerful lawyers voted three years later to divest itself of the property and sell it. After Waldo descendants argued about “fiduciary responsibilities”, it deeded in trust the property to a newly formed local historical society. Ruth gave the land, which was never flooded by man-made causes, to the State of Connecticut to remain as open space in perpetuity. So today the house, a classic full two story, two room deep, central chimney New England farmhouse is a museum with a collection of art, papers, letters, books, furniture, textiles and farming equipment reflecting the taste and history of the seven generations of this family. Built by Edward Waldo (1684-1767) in 1715, the house passed to Zacheus (1715-1810) to Ebenezer (1766-1843) to Ebenezer (1798-1866) to George (1816-1886) to Gerald (1855-1942) and to Ruth (1885-1975). Today the Scotland Historical Society manages the house and trust. In a few years, we will celebrate the house’s tercentennial. The Tour Today Today a visitor can see some of the pieces of furniture that Gennie saw and described in 1871. Normally, a tour starts in the old kitchen, the largest room in the house with its giant fireplace, eight feet wide, five feet tall, raked out every night to preserve the coals for the cold morning, its massive stones warming up the entire first floor. Double hung doors could be opened so that a pair of oxen could haul in the 18” back logs which also helped to hold the fire’s heat all night. It is amazing that the house never burned down; perhaps the ever present wooden bucket of water was used on more than one occasion. The old kitchen was the busiest room in the house, the true heart of the house where generations both worked and lounged. Here perhaps were the happier days that Gennie wants us to remember. A small “birthing” room next to the kitchen saw 36 Waldo births. Here is where the fruits of the harvest from the stingy soil would be chopped, pickled and preserved, where a kettle would always be simmering above the fire and the brick oven warm for baking. Here the aged would mend, perhaps humming psalms together while the young were told to read. Close by the well room, with its barrel full of water and its improbably large hooks for the salmon caught from the river. Then the tool room with its work benches for mending and finally the buttery where bi-weekly, huge quantities of cheese and butter were made in large discs to be carried by ox cart the twelve miles to the whaling ships in Norwich. In these rooms, the family lived out its philosophy that hard work, duty and simple living were the source of dignity and the solutions to any problem. Waldo House Fireplace Kenneth Waldo World War One Letter Gennie’s tour leaves out the upstairs and the garret but a visitor today can see the homespun textiles, the sweetly laced baby clothes, the impossibly small wedding dress, the intricately sewn blankets, one with over 16,000 squares sown by a thirteen year old Waldo. There is a recently constructed library for the family’s collection of books. In the corner of the attic there is a small bedroom where Kenneth, the last Waldo to live in this house would sometimes take refuge. He was a World War One veteran, wounded and shell shocked, and would never be quite the same. After his parent’s death, he lived alone in the house and enjoyed the simple gifts of his natural surroundings. He walked the old Indian trails to hidden trout streams and hunted and trapped for wild game in the hemlock forest. The town’s people might have thought him a little odd but he had sacrificed for his country and some of the Waldos had been a little different. When they did see him in town he seemed to have a twinkle in his eye, a full smile and told a good Yankee joke. Gennie concludes her tour of the house…”but we cannot stay longer, the shadows lengthen, and the golden sunlight coming in at the west window grows fainter…we must draw the blinds and bid the old homestead good night, leaving it to itself once more and its unspoken memories of better days.” Kin Keeper Gennie is what the professionals in American Family Studies call a kin keeper. She preserved the family’s past for its future. Although many generations helped in this pursuit, she is perhaps the most unsung one. She never married and except for teaching for a few years after college and working as a stenographer in New York City later in her life, she lived here in Waldo Valley, where she helped raise her many nieces and nephews, cared for the aged of her multi-generational family, particularly her father who was a wheelchair bound invalid for the last twenty years of his life. She also transcribed hundreds of his letters, which had been returned to the house because as her father, George, said “so that my children may not be so ignorant of me as I unwillingly am of my father”. He was also a kin keeper. There are many fragile, old scrapes of paper, fragments of the Waldos’ lives, in the old house. On one four by two inch note with large handwriting slanting left, attached to one of Gennie’s last bequests she wrote, “This small package of old silver may be divided among my nephews and nieces” - Genevieve Waldo, Scotland, October 28 th , 1932 (my mother’s hundred and tenth birthday) Gennie (First from left) with her Sisters – 1915 Her mother had been dead for 34 years. Gennie dies the next year. The old silver is gone but this reflection on the old Waldo house celebrates Gennie’s hundred and fiftieth-eighth birthday. In another of her kin keeping bequests, she gave to my grandmother, her niece, a thirty acre piece of land, part of the original Waldo homestead, where my grandparents built on a hill the fourth and last Waldo house in this valley. They would also more than double the Waldos’ original land purchases during the early 20 th century but that is another story. They gave most of their land to the State of Connecticut to remain as forest in perpetuity. I look across the old farm fields to two old Waldo houses,“ the river and the hills beyond in this valley which has many “dear happy memories”. I think Gennie and my grandmother would be one of the Waldos to thank me for this reflection. Some twentieth century Waldos would tell me to burn it and get on with my own life. In their self-made- man culture, ancestral reflections become ancestor worship. The Waldos were no better or worse than most. Some smart and able, some were not. Postscript Waldo Valley is remarkably unchanged since Edward traveled east six miles down the Shetucket River from his father’s homestead in Windham to a forested wilderness and built his strong post and beam house. Summer beams and heavy framing with counter corner posts are visible. The house stands alone with no man-made structures in view in contrast to his father’s house, surrounded by housing developments and gravel operators. The river with help from the last glaciers of 10,000 years ago created a broad river valley with rich flood plain fields. Some of the old fields are still farmed although some, as they all will someday, have reverted to woodlands. Black Walnut Tree Waldo Valley A handsome, oldest documented (1798) Black Walnut tree in the State of Connecticut, casts its broad shadow over the house and land. The barns are gone. On the eastern boundary is a large farm, to the west the river, and the hills embrace all. Perhaps the greatest legacy the Waldos left us has been their land bequests to the state of Connecticut’s Department of Environmental Protection. Over 1,000 acres are now protected in perpetuity. This area is called the Mohegan State Forest. The Waldos have preserved their land for their children’s children, for everyone’s children. Cornelius Waldo landed at Ipswich, Massachusetts in the 1640s when there were approximately 20,000 inhabitants of this colony. Today after fourteen generations, genealogists estimate that there are hundreds of thousands of Waldo decedents in this country. If you are interesting in establishing a Waldo Family web page and/or if you are interested in purchasing a book, The Ancestors’ Letters , about this branch of the Waldo family for the Tercentennial of the house, please e-mail me at henryhbowers@gmail.com Come visit, enjoy the natural splendor of this valley. The Scotland Historical Society opens the Waldo House the first Saturday from May to September and there is a Scottish Highland Festival on the grounds in October. name: Historic Endview
address: 362 Yorktown Rd Suite 1017, Newport News, VA 23603, USA
homepage_content: Historic Newport News Skip to the content Historic Endview Historic Endview is one of the last remaining colonial buildings in Newport News. Learn about the people who lived and worked on this site through tours, exhibits, special events and programs throughout the entire year. LEARN MORE Lee Hall Mansion Built between 1851 and 1859, Lee Hall Mansion was home to affluent planter Richard Decatur Lee. One of the last remaining antebellum homes on the Virginia Peninsula, Lee Hall offers visitors a step back to the mid-Victorian period. LEARN MORE Lee Hall Depot Established in 1881, historic Lee Hall Depot is the last remaining station from the C&O Railroad’s expansion into Warwick County, Virginia. LEARN MORE Virginia War Museum American military history unfolds at the Virginia War Museum. Outstanding collections of personal artifacts, weapons, vehicles, uniforms, posters and much more trace the development of the U.S. military from 1775 through the present. LEARN MORE Newsome House Museum & Cultural Center J. Thomas Newsome advocated for education, voter registration, and civil rights for African Americans. His elegant Queen Anne residence served as the hub of the local Black community and the base from which he led the fight for social justice. CLICK HERE HISTORIC NEWPORT NEWS Welcome to Historic Newport News Newport News has a rich cultural heritage with important archaeological sites, beautiful historic homes, extensive Civil War earthworks, and engaging museum galleries. Come explore the City-operated historic sites and museums. Newport News has history for everyone. name: West Virginia Mine Wars Museum
address: 401 Mate St, Matewan, WV 25678, USA
homepage_content: West Virginia Mine Wars Museum WELCOME TO THE WEST VIRGINIA MINE WARS MUSEUM Ten Years of People Powered, People Funded, People’s History. Donate support the work Planning to Visit the Museum? Check out our new Events Calendar for upcoming happenings in Matewan: museum events Nov 25, 2025 We're Hiring a Bookkeeper! Nov 25, 2025 We are excited to announce that we’re looking for a Bookkeeper for the Museum ! Nov 25, 2025 Nov 14, 2025 Stepping into a New Role Nov 14, 2025 As we expand our staff, a familiar face is taking on a new role at the Museum. Nov 14, 2025 Nov 12, 2025 A New Addition to the Museum Nov 12, 2025 Meet our new Communications Director, Taylor Hankins. Nov 12, 2025 Nov 11, 2025 Veterans and the Battle of Blair Mountain Nov 11, 2025 On this Veterans Day we are looking into the contributions of veterans at the Battle of Blair Mountain and how veterans continue to participate in the modern-day labor movement. Nov 11, 2025 Oct 21, 2025 Announcing our 2025 Red Bandana Award Winners! Oct 21, 2025 Every two years at Camp Solidarity, the West Virginia Mine Wars Museum gives awards to individuals or organizations that have made exceptional contributions to economic justice, workers’ rights, or the labor movement—especially in southern West Virginia and more generally across the state. Keep reading to learn about our 2025 Red Bandana Awards. Oct 21, 2025 Oct 10, 2025 Lessons and Legacy from Camp Solidarity 2025 Oct 10, 2025 The week of Camp Solidarity went off nearly without a hitch. We had excellent panels which included a retrospective on the 1984-85 UMWA strike against the A.T. Massey Coal Company (later Massey Energy), Labor and the Green Economy, and how we can build solidarity in the face of encroaching fascism. We also had a panel made up of our Red Bandana Award winners: Jessie Wilkerson, Chris Mark, and Kandi Workman. On top of that, we also added new classes on community benefits agreements, overcoming division, organizing in times of crisis, and how to teach labor history in local union meetings. Oct 10, 2025 “ At this political moment, this museum is essential as a critical voice for workers and their history. ” — Barbara Ellen Smith, board member and author, Digging Our Own Graves Step Inside the Stories… Find out everything you need to know about how to travel to the West Virginia Mine Wars Museum, and where to stay, eat, and visit while you’re here. Visit the Museum NEW! The Fred Barkey Collection We’re honored (and excited!) to introduce a new collection featuring the personal archives of the late Dr. Frederick Barkey , a celebrated labor historian, public storyteller, and people’s scholar… see the collection Bring the History Right to Your Students! We’ve developed a series of “Teaching Trunks” containing artifacts, documents, handouts, and activities that will empower educators to teach a series of immersive lessons focused on the people, events, and themes in the history of the West Virginia Mine Wars. learn more People’s History: Online! Until you can plan your trip to Matewan, spend some time with the online exhibitions we’re curating from the entire catalog of the museum’s collection! Online exhibitions Support Our Work: Shop for Books and Merch Online! Grabbing merchandise from our online shop is an excellent way to support the work we do! We’ve got a new, expanded Mine Wars Bookshop, new t-shirts, hats, sweatshirts, and more! Submit Answer CULTURE CENTER West Virginia Culture Center A New Era of Goldenseal For the first time in the magazine’s history, readers can explore Goldenseal content online for free . Additionally, a commemorative book with print versions of the magazine’s content will be produced each year and made available for purchase by West Virginia history enthusiasts. Welcome! The Culture Center celebrates and preserves the Mountain State’s rich creative spirit, unique cultural traditions, and storied past. From showcasing local artists and musicians to stewarding historic sites and archives, this branch of the Department of Tourism oversees vital programs and facilities. Whether you’re interested in discovering folk art, attending live performances, researching genealogy, or exploring state history, you’ll find it here. In addition to the team at the Culture Center, sister facilities, with a shared mission include Independence Hall , Camp Washington-Carver and Grave Creek Mound Archaeological Complex . To learn more about planning a trip in the state, call a travel advisor at 1-800-CALL-WVA or visit WVtourism.com . MUSEUMS The West Virginia State Museums features locations at the Culture Center, Grave Creek Archaeological Complex, Camp Washington Carver, and Independence Hall. Learn More RECORDS & DATABASES Whether researching your family lineage or looking for information on the history of West Virginia, the Archives and History website is the premier on-line resource. name: Butler-McCook House & Garden
address: 396 Main St, Hartford, CT 06103, USA
homepage_content: Butler-McCook House & Garden – Connecticut Landmarks Skip to content Loading... Butler-McCook House & Garden Pete Hary 2025-10-22T12:38:46-04:00 Butler-McCook House & Garden Hartford’s Oldest House (1782) 396 Main Street, Hartford, CT 06103 butler.mccook@ctlandmarks.org Purchase Tickets PROGRAMS & EVENTS Tour Inquiry Hours Open for tours May through December on the 1st Saturday of the month from 1–4 pm. May 3, June 7, July 5, August 2, September 6, October 4, November 1, December 6, 2025. Tours on the hours; last tour departs one hour before closing. Admission $16 / Adult $12 / Senior, Student, or Teacher $5 / Child 6-18 Free for Connecticut Landmarks Members & Children under Can’t make it to an Open Tour Day? The house is also open by advance reservation and for public programs & events. To arrange a tour or learn more about school group visits, email butler.mccook@ctlandmarks.org . House Tour The Butler-McCook House & Garden is the only 18th-century home remaining on Hartford’s Main Street. It is a time capsule of Hartford’s past and the history of one family. Visitors are taken on a guided tour of the house that primarily focuses on the McCook family’s artistic and intellectual interests during the late 19th century. Guests will learn about a family who loved music, art, and travel through explorations of the museum’s collections, including paintings, Japanese samurai armor, furniture, and toys. Upcoming Tours Programs & Events Art Exhibits at our Hartford Historic Properties May 3, 2025 – April 30, 2026 Stitching History with America’s Tapestry at the Butler-McCook House & Garden December 6 @ 1:00 pm – 4:00 pm A Victorian Holiday with the McCooks December 6 @ 1:00 pm – 4:00 pm A Mid-Century Holiday with the Ishams December 13 @ 1:00 pm – 4:00 pm LEARN MORE For 189 years the Butler-McCook House & Garden was home to four generations of a family who participated in, witnessed, and recorded the evolution of Main Street between the American Revolution and the mid-twentieth century. Inside are the original furnishings ranging from Connecticut-crafted colonial furniture to Victorian-era toys and paintings to samurai armor acquired during a trip to Japan. The objects were accumulated over the course of almost two centuries by members of this extraordinary clan, which included physicians, industrialists, missionaries, artists, globetrotters and pioneering educators and social reformers. The house’s exterior looks much as it did when it was built in 1782. Behind the property is a restored Victorian ornamental garden, originally planned to incorporate the vestiges of an earlier garden by pioneering landscape architect Jacob Weidenmann in 1865. Today, the garden is cared for by the West Hartford Garden Club. The Butler-McCook House is now the oldest remaining home in Hartford. In fact, two of only four remaining 18th-century buildings in Hartford have been preserved thanks to the care of the McCook family. In addition to their family home, they also offered their backyard to preserve the Amos Bull House, which now serves as the headquarters for Connecticut Landmarks. Page load link Go to Top

name: Battle of Aiken
address: 1210 Powell Pond Rd, Aiken, SC 29801, USA
homepage_content: Battle of Aiken – 30th Annual Festival Home 31st Annual Festival of Living History! Friday School Field Trip Feb 21, 2025 Festival Saturday, February 22, & Sunday, February 23, 2025 Since 1995, thousands of spectators travel to Aiken each year to see hundreds of soldiers, and living historians recreate one of the last Confederate victories of the war: The Battle of Aiken. The event commemorates battles that were typical of the engagements during Sherman’s march through Georgia and the Carolinas. The rare Confederate victory in Aiken saved the town from being burned in 1865. This annual weekend event has been awarded the SC Parks, Recreation, and Tourism’s Governor’s award for Best South Carolina Event . In addition, The Battle was also awarded the Dr. James Butler National Award for being the nation’s Best Living History Program. In addition , Reenactment Guide selected the Battle of Aiken as one of the top 10 Reenactments in America! Each year, up to 4,000 children attend one of South Carolina’s largest school field trip programs on Friday to see history come alive! Any public school, private school, or home school may attend the educational program. On Saturday and Sunday, families can step back in time and hear, see, smell, and feel the thunder of cannons, muskets, and horses! Families can tour through numerous stations to interact and learn about Civil War music and dance, Medical Field Hospitals, Uniforms, Confederate and Union Camps, Artillery Batteries, Saber Demonstrations, Cavalry Camps, 1861 Women’s Fashions, Blacksmithing, and other 19th Century Crafts. Spectators can tour an authentic 19th-century log cabin as well as a recreated one-room schoolhouse, jail, and country store. Sunday will feature a historically accurate 19th century Church service. The highlight of the Festival is the weekend’s three dramatic recreated battles on a historically accurate battlefield. Hundreds of historically accurate soldiers recreate the Battle that saved the Town of Aiken from Sherman’s Cavalry. These recreated incidents of the past put up an entertaining dramatic show while educating the public about the War Between the States. . Special New Scenario: Night Fire Saturday at 7 PM! Military historians will fire cannons, mortars, muskets, and an authentic WW2 battle-used flame thrower! See flames shoot 30 yards in front of cannons and the flame thrower! This is a dream opportunity for photographers! In addition, Sherman’s troops will burn a homestead for an upcoming movie! Don’t miss this once-in-a-lifetime experience! 160th Anniversary of Sherman’s March! Meet General Robert E. Lee! General Lee will be on hand each day of the event. Kids may interact and have their photograph taken with the General. David Chaltas is nationally recognized for his portrayal of General Robert E. Lee. Don't Miss the Fun! The Festival is conveniently located near the SC I-20 exit 18 (at Hwy. 19): 1210 Powell Pond Road, Aiken, SC 29801. MAILING ADDRESS: Battle of Aiken, PO Box 1863, Aiken, SC 29802 STAY AND MAKE YOUR OWN HISTORY! CLICK BELOW FOR HOTEL & DINING INFORMATION. Funding assistance has been provided by Aiken County through Accomodation Tax Funds www.DiscoverAikenCounty.com Funding assistance has been provided byThe City of Aiken through Accomodation Tax Funds www.VisitAikenSC.com

name: Cedar Mountain Battlefield
address: 9465 General Winder Rd, Rapidan, VA 22733, USA
homepage_content: Friends of Cedar Mountain Battlefield Discover Cedar Mountain’s Historic Valor On August 9, 1862, the Battle of Cedar Mountain erupted in Culpeper County, Virginia, as Stonewall Jackson’s Confederates clashed with Union forces under Nathaniel Banks. A dramatic rally led to a hard-fought Confederate victory, with over 3,000 casualties. Visit this historic battlefield to walk where heroes fought and history was forged. Donate Become a Member Learn More The Cedar Mountain Battlefield Foundation is a community-based non-profit corporation dedicated to working cooperatively with landowners and local citizens to protect, restore, maintain, manage, interpret, and promote public awareness of the Cedar Mountain Civil War Battlefield and the vicinity of Culpeper County, Virginia. At Cedar Mountain, Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson led his troops into battle on August 9, 1862 against Nathaniel Banks’ corps of John Pope’s new Army of Virginia. Over 3,000 men were killed or wounded that afternoon and evening in the shadow of Cedar Mountain during the deadliest day in Culpeper’s history. Culpeper’s native son, Major General A. P. Hill, sealed the Confederate victory when his division reformed Jackson’s crumbled line and led the charge that turned the tide of the battle. For Hill and the other Culpeper men engaged, this was a personal battle to liberate their homes, friends and family from the Union occupation. With the support of local citizens and the American Battlefield Trust, the Cedar Mountain Battlefield Foundation is working to ensure that this battle and the valor displayed by both armies will never be forgotten. name: Leffingwell House Museum
address: 348 Washington St, Norwich, CT 06360, USA
homepage_content: Leffingwell House Museum The Leffingwell House Museum (Circa 1675), is a fine example of New England Colonial architecture showing the architectural development common to CT. In 1675 it started as a two room home, then in 1701 evolved into a pre-Revolutionary Tavern and by 1776 became the elegant townhouse of Norwich Patriot Christopher Leffingwell. Interpreters use displays of artifacts, dating from the founding of Norwich in 1659 through the Civil War, to evoke the lifestyle of early America. The Joseph Carpenter Silversmith Shop was built in 1772, when the Norwichtown Green was the social and commercial center of the town. Appreciate the original walls and the forge of the silversmith as well as displays of the businesses and craftsmen of Norwichtown . Museum Hours: Open April through October Leffingwell is open Saturday: 11am-3pm ($8/pp) The Silversmith Shop is open Saturday: 11am-3pm. ($5/pp) Tours by appointment available, contact us at info@leffingwellhousemuseum.org Stay connected with us on Facebook Enjoy our Leffingwell House Museum Pictures Leffingwell House Museum Colonial Garden Colonial Kitchen A Tour at the Leffingwell Brick walkway Flag on chair Tavern table Centennial Flag Colonial Cloth Room Be Revolutionary Hannah Tracy Huntington's Sample Powder Horns and Pewter Soldiers Chamber Leffingwell House Museum Our Colonial Gardens MENU Visit Our Museums Leffingwell 350 2025 Events: 350th Anniversary Hours & Directions Membership Donations Contact Us Our Historic Buildings Society of the Founders of Norwich Membership by Descent Give Your Support- Buy a Brick! name: Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum
address: 50 S River Ave, Weston, WV 26452, USA
homepage_content: Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum – Historic and Paranormal Tours Tour this National Historic Landmark! Welcome to the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum located in Historic Weston, West Virginia. This National Historic Landmark served as a sanctuary for the mentally ill in the mid-1800s. This 160-year-old asylum holds fascinating stories. It includes Civil War raids and a gold robbery. There are also stories about the “curative” effects of architecture. The efforts of determined individuals helped better the lives of the mentally ill. Tour this nationally recognized historic landmark and see how it left a lasting impression on local and national history. During our season, we offer a variety of historic and paranormal tours. Ghost hunts of this massive building run year-round. Walk-in tours will resume on March 28th, 2026. Historic Tours will leave every hour on the hour . Paranormal Tours leave every 2 hours. The last 45-minute tour leaves at 5:00 p.m., and the 90-minute tour leaves at 4:00 p.m. Tour Hours Note: Please dress appropriately for the current weather conditions. It is hotter in the summer and colder in the winter inside the building. renovation26 banner_ghsale Click the banners above and find more ways to explore the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum. Learn about our year-round events and other opportunities! View Detailed Schedule of Events Office hours Monday – Friday 9:00 a.m. – 5:00 p.m. Can’t find what you are looking for email us at info@talawv.com or call 304-269-5070. No drones allowed.
