name: Sugar Hill Historical Museum
address: 1400 NH-117, Sugar Hill, NH 03586, USA
homepage_content: Sugar Hill Historical Museum | Sugar Hill New Hampshire Skip to content Sugar Hill New Hampshire Incorporated in 1962 Departments Buildings/Grounds & Cemetery Fire Department Highway Department Lafayette Recreation and Tri Town Transfer Station Police Department Select Board Office Town Clerk/Tax Collector Boards and Committees Cemetery Trustees Conservation Commission Planning Board Select Board Sugar Hill Broadband Committee Supervisors of the Checklist Trustee of the Trust Funds Zoning Board & Minutes 2011-2025 Library and Museum Richardson Memorial Library Sugar Hill Historical Museum Calendar Forms Links Northern Pass Town Ordinances EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT & PREPAREDNESS Community Power Sugar Hill Historical Museum 2025 Celebrating Sugar Hill Winters OPENING FOR THE SEASON MAY 23rd, 2025 TO OCTOBER 13th, 2025 Located beside the Sugar Hill village green (across from the old post office), this museum includes information of this scenic hillside town from 1780 to the present. Our campus consists of two barns, one main building, and the Reid-Burpee house adjacent to the Carriage Barn. The Carriage Barn is filled with tools, horse-drawn carriages, folk-style paintings of old Sugar Hill, and a Benjamin Morrill tower clock. The second barn, the Sleigh Shed, displays a vast and growing collection of historic public signs and sleighs, including one sleigh from the Bette Davis estate. It also garages the 1939 Ford fire Truck#2 given to the newly formed sugar Hill Fire Department in 1948 by Henry Crapo. This Ford truck, originally a farm truck, was retro-fitted by the firemen. When the museum is open, the fire truck magically appears on the front lawn. The main building contains extensive photograph archives, a local history and genealogy library, the John E. Bigelow Gallery, public room, a gift shop, and a unique main gallery exhibit which changes annually to reflect the history of sugar Hill’s people and places. Admission is free. Memberships and donations are encouraged. Special tours may be arranged during the season. Contact Curator-Director Kitty Bigelow at 603-823-5275. Visit http://www.sugarhillnh.org/library-and-museum-sugar-hill-historical-museum/ and find us on Facebook at Sugar Hill Historical Museum. Contact: Kitty Bigelow, Executive Director, PO Box 591, Sugar Hill, NH 03586 Phone: 603-823-5336 Museum Email: kittyh41@gmail.com Website: www.sugarhillnh.org/library-and-museum/sugar-hill-historical-museum/ Volunteers make a difference and we have the best! History: The Sugar Hill Historical Museum began as a bicentennial project by a group of very enthusiastic residents who were concerned about creating a home for the history of Sugar Hill. The original building was a schoolhouse moved stick by stick from the neighboring town of Easton to the present spot by the newly formed Sugar Hill Fire Department. In 1948, radiant heat caused a fire in the school, and the building eventually became a four-stall firehouse. When the new fire department building opened in in 1975, the vacant building was renovated and reopened in 1976 as the Sugar Hill Historical Museum. Cultural Statement: Our purpose is to be an educational resource for the public through research, study, collection, preservation and exhibition of artifacts that illustrate the history of our community. name: Littleton Historical Museum
address: 2 Union St, Littleton, NH 03561, USA
homepage_content: About Us – The Littleton area historical museum Skip to content Who we are The Littleton Area Historical Museum is a 501c3 organization that was started in 1967. It originally started in the public library and is now in the Town Building (Opera House). We are the caretakers and keepers of Littleton's past. Our volunteers work to maintain the hundreds of artifacts that are on display as well as the many carefully planned exhibits. We have documents dating back to the late 18th Century, written by the early settlers of our town. We are constantly organizing and updating our collection. We are the present, preserving the past, for the future! Board of Directors: President: Dick Searles V P: Curtis Metzger Secretary: Barb Radmore Treasurer: Roger Merrill Sue Pilotte Jim Radmore Mark Roberts Ray Hopkins (Emeritus) Curator: Clarissa M. Palmer, PhD Curator Emeritus: Dick Alberini Volunteers Our volunteers are critical to the success of the Museum! From exhibit design to special events, our volunteers step up to make a huge impact in how Littleton history is shared with visitors. If you would like to discuss your interest in becoming a volunteer at the Littleton Historical Museum, please reach out at (603) 444-6435 or lhistoricalsociety@gmail.com Volunteers include: Jan, Elaine, Eric, Connor (student volunteer), Molly (student volunteer), and Dick Alberini! Our Board Members are also volunteers and help support the Museum in many, many ways! Copyright © 2025 The Littleton area historical museum — Stout theme by GoDaddy

name: Living History Days
address: Corporate office, 2901 Sheridan Boulevard, Wheat Ridge, CO 80214, USA
homepage_content: Living History Days – Step Back in Time to the 18th Century Skip to content Living History Days provides a great opportunity for you and your family to experience history hands-on. We do this by hosting and participating in historical interpretation events and celebrations to educate about 18 th -century colonial American life, history, ideas, and values through costumed interpreters, hands-on activities, and military demonstrations. Visit Living History Days Step back in time to 18th Century America. Visit Living History Days. Posted by Living History Days on Sunday, April 8, 2018 Step back in time to the 18th century and experience the excitement of building a new nation. Current Event – Fall 2025 Encampment Setting: 1777, Danbury, Connecticut When September 26-27, 2025 Friday & Saturday 9:00AM–4:00PM Where Red Rocks Baptist Church 14711 W Morrison Rd Morrison, CO 80465 Dogs are not permitted. Event Details Map and Directions, Cost, Project Sign-up, Schedule, etc. Future Event – Spring 2026 Encampment Setting: 1776 When April 24-25, 2026 Friday & Saturday 9:00AM–4:00PM Where Red Rocks Baptist Church 14711 W Morrison Rd Morrison, CO 80465 Other Events These are events and celebrations that we also participate in: Annually beginning of May – Fort Lupton Heritage Fair | Ft Lupton, CO Annually in July – Fort Russell Days | Cheyenne, WY Experience 18th-century life through costumed interpreters, hands-on activities, and military demonstrations. Aspects of colonial American life will be available for you to experience – agriculture, blacksmith, education, games, gunsmith, military, and much more. 1777 – Colonial Location – Saratoga, New York British General John Burgoyne, in an attempt to cut New England off from the rest of the colonies, has begun invading from Canada with his 7,000 troops. Having already captured Fort Ticonderoga, the troops make their way South to New York. On September 19, 1777, they will meet a force of 9,000 continentals under the command of General Horatio Gates at Freeman’s Farm, just 9 miles outside of Saratoga. 18th-Century Military Demonstration – twice daily Both Continental and British troops will demonstrate 18th-century military maneuvers. Though similar, you will learn the differences between the two opposing forces. This will be introduced by a rousing fife and drum march and a booming artillery demonstration. Medical Demonstration – Immediately after each battle Stop at the surgeon tent to learn about 18th-century medicine. Several surgical techniques will be demonstrated. Candle Dipping – All day Made from beeswax and beef tallow. Come and dip your own candle to light the way before the shorter nights of winter arrive. $3 each (paid at registration tent). Cider Press – All day Cider was one of the most common beverages of the colonies. Come try the press and then drink some of the fruits of your labor ( apple harvest permitting) . Projects – see project page for times We offer optional hands-on crafts to make something special to take home. Space is limited and pre-registration is recommended. JOIN US! When September 26-27, 2025 Friday & Saturday 9:00AM–4:00PM Where Red Rocks Baptist Church 14711 W Morrison Rd Morrison, CO 80465 Dogs are not permitted. Admission $5/person (age 4+) Max $20/family Friday : Open to everyone, but preregistration required for field trip discount. Saturday : Open to everyone, $4/person for homeschool groups, no preregistration required. We require each family to fill out a Liability Waiver . Save time, and print at home. Print each guest’s name, and have each adult sign. Children under 18 are not required to sign, so long as a parent or guardian has signed. Map & Directions Print Waiver Project Sign-Up Frequently Asked Queries Join our E-post list to Get News regarding our eventS [instagram-feed] Pray thee, have you any queries? Here are some of common ones and answers. How do I pay admission? Payment is made upon entry to the encampment. We accept cash, checks, and credit/debit cards (w e do not accept Continentals due to British counterfeiting and their depreciating value ). What is the admission price? $5 per person. Children under 4 are free, and an immediate family is $20. On Friday, we offer a discount for school field trips, $4/person for field trips, and on Saturday we offer a discounted price of $4/person for home-school groups with no limit on the number of people. Do school groups and field trips have a discount? If you are a schoolmaster, bringing 10 or more people, then the price is $4 per person. Pre-registration is required . Each child will need to have a liability waiver. Please download the liability waiver and have the parents/guardians of each child sign one. When you arrive, have one adult proceed to the line marked for school groups to pick up all the wristbands for your group. While within the encampment, please have a chaperone with each group of children. I am a home-schooler, may I have the school discount? Aye, if you meet the requirements for school groups above you may pre-register as a field trip on Friday. However, if you come on Saturday, you can just tell the people at the registration tent the name of your home-school Co-op or group, and you can pay $4 per person or $20 per family. Please come on Saturday if you can, it is less busy. Do I need to preregister my school group? Yes, if you want the $4/person price, there is an online form for field trip registrations. Please read the terms and conditions carefully. If you want to come for $5/person, just arrive anytime after 9 am, no need to pre-register. Will there be refreshments for sale? Ginger cookies, drinks, and other snacks are for sale in our general store, but there will not be any items for dinner, the mid-day meal. You are welcome to bring your own provisions, and eat it outside of the encampment display area. We recommend that you bring full canteens as well. You are also welcome to leave and return as many times as you need during the two-day event to go get food. There are taverns, markets and other establishments within 10-15 minutes of our locations. What should we bring? To be sure you have an exceedingly agreeable time, we recommend planning for any sort of weather. It is often prodigiously sunny and hats, bonnets, canteens, and sunscreen are recommended. Feel free to don any 18th-century attire you wish. A form of payment for admission as well as to purchase items from the general store. To expedite your entry print and bring your liability form . I purchased a doll dress kit. How do I sew it? You may download the instructions. Please choose the appropriate one: doll dress with pinner cap or doll dress with mob cap . Lose something at the event? We have a lost and found at the registration table that you can inquire at during the event. Otherwise, you may contact found@livinghistorydays.com . Any children left behind will be bound out into apprenticeships. May I bring my dog? No animals are allowed to be brought to the event due to the crowds, the gunpowder, and the livestock that we’ll have on display. Have you other queries? Please contact us at queries@livinghistorydays.com

Explore event calendars and seasonal highlights like the Christmas Village! Learn More Who We Are In 1973 Our Mission Heritage Farm Museum & Village was born from the passion of co-founders Mike and Henriella Perry in 1973. After moving to a historic 150-acre farm, they uncovered the hidden beauty of old log structures, inspiring them to honor the hardworking spirit of their Appalachian ancestors. Vibrant Educational Destination: Since 1996, Heritage Farm has featured multiple museums showcasing the rich and unique stories of Appalachian life, from daily life in the 19th century to artisan demonstrations. Hands-On History: Guests can engage in interactive experiences that bring history alive, including hands-on activities that celebrate our heritage and culture. Adventure and Resilience: Our Adventure Park offers thrilling outdoor experiences, reflecting the adventurous spirit of past generations and highlighting the adaptability and creativity of Appalachian people. The mission of Heritage Farm Foundation is to be a source of hope and renewal to the people of Appalachia by sharing their proud, rugged past with the world in ways that inspire an emboldened, vibrant future. ​ Join us as we make a vibrant future while honoring our past. - Stunning Moments from Heritage Farm Museum & Village - Explore Our Gallery View Gallery - Our Events - Upcoming Events Stay connected with all the happenings at Heritage Farm! Our 2025 Season Thursday - Friday - Saturday May 1st - November 1st 10:30 am - 3 pm Festival Days and June/July Saturdays - Open until 5 pm. *We Are Closed Aug. 17th-30th* 2025 Festival Dates Spring Festival: Saturday, May 3rd Summer Festival: Saturday, July 5th Fall Festival: Saturday, September 27th - Our Testimonials - What Our Visitors Are Saying See More “I am a family pass holder and have been for 5+ years. I have been taking my family numerous times each year, and now with added attractions we have been 6 times this past year with the highlight being the Christmas Village. Every time I go into the museums I notice something new and exciting. The staff/volunteers are the best!” Marty “This place is an amazing way to spend an afternoon! I came here with my girlfriend and despite being a little more geared towards kids, we had a blast. Between the petting zoo, the museums, and the awesome staff, we had a great time. Entry tickets are not expensive and they're good for an entire day, which is usually open for 5 hours a day. Along with some of the activities, you can purchase tickets for a zip liner, mountain biking, and taking a 4 wheeler through the mountains. Everyone in the family can find something to do here!” Colin Support Us Become a Friend of the Farm Join Heritage Farm's Friends of the Farm Giving Program and help us preserve the rich heritage of Appalachia! By becoming a Friend, you'll enjoy unlimited visits, exclusive events, and discounts on rentals while taking pride in supporting West Virginia's first Smithsonian Affiliate. Support the Farm bottom of page

name: Hillsborough Historical Society
address: 5 Central St, Hillsborough, NH 03244, USA
homepage_content: Front Page - Hillsborough Historical Society Skip to content Once home to more than a dozen stone arch bridges, Hillsborough still has five of these gems, four of which are used everyday to support auto, bike and foot traffic. The Heritage Museum is Hillsborough's refurbished Fire House. Our displays include the original Hillsborough Grange Hall Theater Curtains and the MPM Photo Collection. A treasure trove of searchable historic images. The Manahan-Phelps-McCulloch Collection is a collection of more than 250,000 images from a photographic studio in continuous operation in Hillsborough from the early 1860's. The studio originally opened under the ownership of Solon Newman, and has changed ownership many times over the years. Starting in 1899, William H. Manahan Jr. ran the studio for 54 years until Cyrus Phelps took over in 1953. In 2002, Donald McCulloch and Catherine Phelps McCulloch, the final proprietors, donated the collection to the Hillsborough Historical Society. The society has been preserving and documenting the collection ever since. Museum volunteers would be happy to assist you in our research area during normal hours on Wednesday and Saturday. Click for our latest Hillsborough Historical News!

name: Norlands Living History Center
address: 290 Norlands Rd, Livermore, ME 04253, USA
homepage_content: Home - Norlands Skip to content Fall Season Hours Office/ Business Hours 9:30am – 4pm Tues.- Sat. Tours 2pm Tuesday – Friday 11am & 2pm Saturday The Fall Season has begun! Come visit us for School & Homeschool Programs, Farm-to-Table Dinners, Special Events and Historical Site Tours. Enjoy the grounds and our trails during daylight hours any day of the week. At the Norlands, Fall means field trips – a favorite memory for generations of Mainers. Our school age programs typically last from 9:30am until 2pm. In addition to our scheduled tours, we welcome tours by appointment in the fall. Please, send us an email, fill out a tour request, or for same-day appointments give us a call. If you have a group of 10 or more, please contact us about creating a special experience at the Norlands. We hope to see you soon! Please note that tours are paid for upon arrival. Discover the Washburn Norlands The Washburn Norlands is a 400-acre estate that includes a stately Victorian country mansion with a farmer’s cottage, a gothic-style granite library, a Universalist meetinghouse, a one-room schoolhouse, an expanse of picturesque working farmland, historic carriage trails, and an expansive archive of 19th century documents and ephemera. Click here to join us for Tours, Events, Farm to Table Dinners, & More! Upcoming Events Mansion Dinner & Fashion Collection September 12 Farm-to-Table Barn Dinners September 20 & 26 Haunted Harvest October 25 Veteran's Day Dinner in the Mansion November 8 Olde Fashioned Christmas at Norlands December 5, 6 & 7 Schedule your Visit The Norlands is open for individual and group tours by appointment Tuesday - Saturday in the Spring and Fall season. Summer tours do not require an appointment. Our tours include an in-depth look at the Washburn Mansion as well as the Schoolhouse, Library, and Meeting House. Please call for same day tours. Request a Visit Become a Member To help preserve the Norlands, please become a member. Your membership supports our essential operations, making it possible for us to remain open all year. Plus, you receive free admission to Norlands all year and discounts on meals and special events. Click here Join us for a Farm-to-Table Meal Get a taste of Maine at farm-to-table meals at the Norlands in the barn and the Mansion. Our farmer/chef, Emelia Robbins, has designed a series of classic Maine meals featuring seasonal products from Livermore area family-owned farms. Dinners are held June - September. Click Here Come to School in 1870 When you bring your class, camp, scout troop or youth group to the Washburn Norlands Living History Center, volunteer and staff interpreters lead your students in an educational and historical experience as if it were the 19th century. Click Here I enjoyed participating in a one room, school house, lesson of reading, writing, math, and penmanship. The baked goodies from the cast-iron stove were delicious. And having a family member share the multi generational history of this place was so cool. F.G.R. Visitor July 15 This place is a hidden gem. So much interesting history. M.T.L. Visitor June 30 Everyone was so friendly and knowledgeable! Lovely interactive experience and so much to see! The goats were a hit. J.A. Visitor July 14 We really enjoyed our visit to Norlands this past Friday. The staff were both pleasant and professional. The history is quite alive at the Washburn home! Thanks again for a memorable time! Michael Bell Manchester, ME Who were the remarkable Washburns who built Norlands, led states and people, invented, explored, innovated and always returned home to Maine? Maine Governor Israel Washburn, Congressman & Republican Party Founder Algernon Sydney Washburn, Bank of Hallowell President Congressman Elihu B. Washburne, Ambassador to France General Cadwallader C. Washburn, Wisconsin Governor, Congressman, and founder of Gold Medal Flour Martha Benjamin Washburn Stephenson Ambassador Charles Ames Washburn, Inventor and Author Capt. Samuel Washburn Mary Washburn Buffum Senator William Drew Washburn, Congressman & founder of Pillsbury Flour Caroline Ann Washburn Holmes When you bring your class, camp, scout troop, or youth group to the Washburn Norlands Living History Center, volunteer and staff interpreters lead your students in an educational and historical experience as if it were the 19th century. Each session is within the capacity of today’s learners and they gain an understanding of what life was like in this crossroads neighborhood of Livermore, Maine. Small groups participate in a variety of activities throughout the buildings on the Washburn Norlands campus. name: World War II History Center
address: 119 W Central Ave, El Dorado, KS 67042, USA
homepage_content: World War II History Center Foundation Search this site Embedded Files Skip to main content Skip to navigation The World War II History Center is a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization (EIN 05-0631890) operated entirely by volunteers. Your support is needed and appreciated. Open Saturdays, 12:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. except holidays or when the "Open" sign is displayed. Special visits may be arranged by appointment. Time Travel Christmas Join us on December 6th at noon when World War II expert Joan Reichardt will take us back to Christmas on the warfront. Joan Reichardt is a teacher at Augusta High School, specializing in World War II history. She earned a Bachelors of Science in Education and a Masters of Arts in Teaching Social Studies from Emporia State. She began her teaching career in Augusta. This is her thirty-fourth year in education. Reichardt’s father was a WWII vet. He was in the Navy at the very end of the war and saw no action but he was at Bikini Atoll the summer of 1946 for Operation Crossroads, the test of two atomic bombs on naval vessels. She understands that the WWII generation was the greatest generation and their sacrifices should be held as an example for current and future generations. “WWII is the watershed event of modern history,” she says. “The lesson we should have learned from the events of WWII and the Holocaust must be taught and hopefully not ignored now or in the future. Enjoy a half hour of coffee and conversation. Learn how our heroes spent their holidays. Then stick around to help us decorate our Christmas tree. 2025 Fundraising Raffle Congratulations to A. Williams of El Dorado! He's the winner of the M1 Garand Raffle! Thanks to everyone who participated. The fundraiser was a great success for the Museum. Stay tuned for next year's raffle, to be announced Q1 of 2026! Donate on PayPal! A buck a month does make a difference! It's tax deductible and just a couple of clicks! name: Jillson House Museum & Windham CT Historical Society
address: 627 Main St, Willimantic, CT 06226, USA
homepage_content: Home | Jillson House Museum top of page Welcome to the Jillson House Museum, home of the Windham Historical Society. Please stop by any Saturday for a tour or attend one of our upcoming events that are listed below or on our events page. Welcome! Supported by the Windham Historical Society NEW!! "MAKING" Workshop Series Download schedule of workshops Thank you to all of our guests to our many programs at the Jillson House Museum. We have been listening to you and have put together a year long series of hands on workshops about making things that you normally buy at the store. For those folks who are interested in "homesteading" skills, 18th c. skills, or just like to make things this is for YOU! Workshops are on the second Saturday of the month from 10 AM-Noon (with one exception). This is what makes these workshops special: 1. You have talented presenters who will demonstrate how to make things 2. You get a free history lesson about the topic! 3. You will enjoy a homemade treat and beverage at every event. 4. You make things at the workshop and take them home. 5. Your take home items are your inspiration for a new hobby. 6. Your packet contains instructions, recipes and resources. ​ There is very limited space so please register early. Cost is $30 per person and includes instruction, food and your own handmade gifts. We need to know who is coming to order the appropriate supplies so please register at least one week before the class. Supported in part by the Leo J. & Rose Pageau Trust. The Town of Windham The town of Windham, located in northeastern Connecticut, is in the southwestern corner of Windham County along the Natchaug River. Incorporated in 1692, Windham originally included the current towns of Mansfield and Scotland , as well as parts of Chaplin and Hampton . It was not until 1857, when the last of these areas incorporated, that Windham took on its current shape. The town of Windham includes the city of Willimantic, which consolidated with Windham upon the dissolution of the city government in 1983. Named after Wyndam, England, the town’s early industry included numerous mills that brought Windham renown as a leader in thread manufacturing. --CTHistory.org Visit CTHistory.org What's New? We keep growing and upgrading....... Anita Sebestyen Fashion Exhibit In memory of our President, Anita Sebestyen, who left us way too early this past year, we have dedicated our front parlor to her with a new exhibit on fashion in the early 1900's. Please visit to enjoy the roarin' 20's and the flappers as well as WWI era uniforms. Hots, gloves and other beautiful accessories are on display. Admission is free. New Storm Windows This year we received a $10,000 matching grant from the 1772 Foundation to remove the old plexiglass from 1975 that was covering our windows with brand new glass storm windows. The old plexiglass was yellowed and scratched and did not allow us to look out our windows. It also made the beautiful building look run down. The transformation is amazing. Please take notice if you are driving by. Thanks to Pat Brady for his work. My Town My Story The Windham Historical Society and the Windham Region Chamber of Commerce partnered with CT Humanities, UCONN and CT Archives to create My Town My Story, a digital archive to record the personal and family histories of Windham residents. Upload your photos and write a brief description. Go HERE to add your history! A New Skirt We placed stone around our foundation to help push water away and preserve our building. Thanks goes to Dan McClintock of McClintock Roofing and Ernie Eldridge of E.S. Auctioneers for doing all the physical work in the rain! Our Current & Upcoming Exhibits Experience Windham CT from 1700's to present "Portrait of a Town" Art and Culture in Windham Ongoing This exhibit celebrates the arts and humanities throughout Windham's history including information about the Frog Bridge, artists Lou Frink, quilting, embroidery, music and other creative people. The exhibit is free Fashion in the Early 1900's Ongoing Learn all about fashion in the early 1900's, the accessories, the styles based on your social standing in the community, and what the Jillson's and their relatives would have worn. Beautiful dresses and accessories on exhibit. ​ We have exclusive items from the Jillson family, one of the founding families in Windham. ​ In Memory of Anita Sebestyen, President, Windham Historical Society Windham Residents in the Miltary-Honoring our Brave Coming in November Join us in honoring those brave individuals who have served our country starting from our early settlers who fought beside George Washington and signed the Declaration of Independence. We have memorabilia and artifacts from each war with interesting facts and the names of those Windham residents who served. This exhibit is our contribution to the 250th Anniversary of the USA and will open throughout 2026 as part of that celebration. TAVERN NIGHTS Are you a foodie? Like to eat? Like to sample new things? But most of all...... you LOVE history!!! We have just the right night for you. Join us monthly at our Tavern Nights where our guest of honor for the evening is a famous person (well, actually an actor portraying them). You will learn about their contributions to their community, their family life, their oddities and quirks, but you will also learn about what their favorite food and beverage was. Not only learn...but you will get to sample their favorites. Stop by after work with friends or make it a midweek date night. The more people the more fun! Featured guests so far have been: Teddy Roosevelt, Marilyn Monroe, Katherine Hepburn, Elvis Presley, Paul Revere Julia Child, President Ronald Reagan and President & Mrs. Abraham Lincoln (photo). Download a schedule of Tavern Nights guests President Abraham Lincoln and his wife , Mary Todd Lincoln shared stories about their family and life in the White House. Mrs. Lincoln shared her terrible experience being committed to a mental institution because doctors did not know what "anemia" was at the time. Tavern Night With Charles Dickens Dec 17, 2025, 5:00 PM – 6:30 PM Jillson House Museum, 627 Main St, Willimantic, CT 06226, USA More info Buy Tickets Upcoming Events: Jillson House is a Hospitality Center! This spring the Jillson House Museum became an official "Hospitality Center" on the East Coast Greenway, open to the public every Saturday from 10:00 AM-4:00 PM. Bikers and hikers can stop in to warm up, get cooled off, evade the rain, use the restrooms, get a snack or hydrating beverage, repair their bike, use our basic first aid kit and, most importantly, park their bikes and take a trip into Willimantic's historic downtown for lunch, dinner or a homemade brew. Free tours of the museum are also available for any visitor, as well as maps and biking information and events. Please stop in and see us! Thanks to our partners and sponsors: East Coast Greenway Alliance, Trust For Public Land, Air Line Trail, Windham Region Chamber of Commerce, Willimantic Rotary and American Savings Foundation. bottom of page

name: Veterans' Rock
address: 605 S Greeley Hwy, Cheyenne, WY 82007, USA
homepage_content: Help Veterans in Need | Veterans' Rock in Cheyenne, WY 0 Supporting Veterans and Active Duty: Donate Today We recognize the sacrifices made by our brave service members and strive to support them in any way possible. Donations are greatly appreciated to help our veterans in need! DONATE HERE! Veterans' Rock in Wyoming assists veterans and active duty in need through supportive services that build toward self-sufficiency. Supportive services include providing food, clothing, furniture, emergency shelter, transportation, phone and computer access, laundry and shower facilities, document retrieval and storage, self-sufficiency plan development, and advocacy. Donate Today Transportation We give cars that have been donated to Veterans' Rock to veterans in need of transportation. Veterans must have a job or be going to school, have a driver license or be able to obtain one, and have or be able to obtain auto insurance. We have given four cars to date. Donate today. Your donation is tax deductible. Veteran Services Food Pantry Our food pantry is free of charge to veterans in need . Visit us during open hours. Includes canned goods, variety of snacks, local meat, eggs, milk, fresh produce, bread, coffee, & more. Our goal is to ensure veterans have access to healthy food to support their overall health and well-being. Veteran Services Support For Our Veterans Rock solid support for veterans, active duty in need, and their families. They fought for our freedom; now we must help them live free of everyday burdens in small impactful ways. Through small but impactful services—like food, shelter, transportation, and advocacy—we strive to make a meaningful difference in their lives. Veteran Services Clothing, Personal Care, and Gear We carry a large selection of clothing items, personal care essentials, and gear that are provided to veterans in need free of charge. From warm coats and boots to hygiene products and everyday necessities, we ensure those who served have access to the essentials they deserve. Veteran Services Computer Facility Our computer facility is equipped with printers and scanners, providing veterans with essential tools for job searches, resume building, and document retrieval. It also offers access to email, virtual medical appointments, and other critical online resources, helping veterans stay connected and take steps toward self-sufficiency. Veteran Services Become a Veterans’ Rock Advocate Our veterans face real challenges—navigating paperwork, securing vital documents like DD-214s, accessing VA benefits, and applying for SSI/SSDI. These hurdles can stand between them and a stable, self-sufficient life. At Veterans’ Rock in Cheyenne, we’re looking for compassionate, detail-oriented advocates who can help break down those barriers. If you’re skilled in organization, communication, or just have a heart for helping, we invite you to join our ROCK solid support team. We provide the tools—you bring your time and dedication. Use our computers, phones, scanners, and supplies to help a veteran move forward. Even just a couple hours a week can make a life-changing difference. Ready to help? Call us today and become part of something truly meaningful. Now Offering Internship Opportunities Are you looking to gain hands-on experience while making a real impact in the lives of veterans and active duty service members? Veterans’ Rock is now offering internship positions for students and community members interested in nonprofit work, advocacy, social services, and administrative support. Interns will have the chance to work directly with our team, assist veterans with essential paperwork and benefits, and learn how grassroots organizations make a difference. We provide all the tools you need—including computers, office supplies, and mentorship—to help you grow while giving back. Whether you're earning class credit or just want meaningful experience, we’d love to hear from you. Apply today and be part of the ROCK solid support system our veterans deserve. internship information here! Make a Difference Dedicated to supporting veterans and active duty service members in need, we provide essential resources that promote independence and stability. Services include food, clothing, furniture, emergency shelter, transportation, and technology access, along with laundry and shower facilities, document storage, self-sufficiency planning, and advocacy. Through generous community donations—whether clothing, household items, or financial support—we make a meaningful difference, helping those who served to regain stability and build brighter futures. Contact us to learn more about how to volunteer/donate to your local veterans donation center! Donation items include clothing, food items, household/miscellaneous supplies, and monetary contributions. 858 & COUNTING Veterans that we have assisted! Thank you to all who have donated to our veterans and active service members. Your generosity provides food, clothing, shelter, transportation, and essential resources that change lives. Because of you, we are able to support more veterans each day, helping them regain stability, independence, and a sense of community. We couldn’t do this without you! Our Team

address: 5815 Battle Fld Trl, Sanderson, FL 32087, USA
homepage_content: Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park | Florida State Parks Skip to main content Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park Florida’s largest Civil War battle is remembered at its battlefield Hours 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Fees No entrance fee is required. A special event fee is charged during the Battle of Olustee Reenactment in February. Location 5815 Battlefield Trail Road Olustee FL 32087 Get directions Contact Info 386-758-0400 Welcome to Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park This park tells the story of Florida's largest Civil War battle, which took place Feb. 20, 1864. More than 10,000 cavalry, infantry and artillery troops fought a five-hour battle in a pine forest near Olustee. Three U.S. Colored Troops took part in the battle, including the now famous 54th Massachusetts. The battle ended with 2,807 casualties and the retreat of Union troops to Jacksonville until the war's end just 14 months later. In 1912, when many living Civil War veterans still attended reunions, the battlefield became the state's first historic site. Visitors can enjoy a meal at the picnic area or take a walk along a mile-long trail that has interpretive signs describing the events of the battle. A reenactment is held every February . Scenes for Civil War movies, including the 1989 movie "Glory," have been filmed during the reenactments. Plan Your Visit Learn Manager's Message Explore Florida's oldest state park and one of Florida's largest Civil War battles. Bring a picnic lunch, take a hike on our trails and learn about our famous history. Learn Battle of Olustee Reenactment History comes alive every February at the annual Civil War Reenactment of the Battle of Olustee. Living history, authentic encampments and reenactors bring Florida history to the forefront during this event at Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park. Learn Walk the Interpretive Trail The park is open year-round, 365 days a year from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., and a visitor center, trails and monument guide visitors through the battle in February in 1864. Experiences Geo-Seeking Hiking Picnicking Amenities Accessible Amenities Historic Site Parking Pets Restroom Facilities Visitor Center Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park Photo Gallery Learn Wild Places of Olustee Not just known for the history of the famous battle, visitors to Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park can see abundant animal and plant life in this wild and wonderful place. Learn History of Olustee Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park commemorates the site of Florida’s largest Civil War battle. For more than 100 years, Olustee has welcomed visitors to walk its grounds and remember one of our nation’s bloodiest conflicts. Upcoming Events See More Events Event Olustee Reenactment Fri, Feb 13 - 15, 2026 8:00 am - 4:00 pm EDT Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park will commemorate the 162nd anniversary of the Civil War and host the 49th Annual Reenactment of the Battle of Olustee Feb. 13-15, 2026. Volunteer Spotlight James Permane began reading about the Civil War at a very young age, finding he was drawn to learn as much as he could about our nation’s greatest conflict. name: Justin Smith Morrill Homestead
address: 214 Justin Morrill Memorial Hwy, Strafford, VT 05072, USA
homepage_content: Senator Justin Morrill | State Historic Sites Skip to main content Search Submit Home Hours of Operation Bennington Battle Monument Mount Independence Chimney Point Senator Justin Morrill Exhibits Research Hours, Admissions, Directions Trails President Calvin Coolidge President Chester Arthur Hubbardton Battlefield Old Constitution House Eureka Schoolhouse Ethan Allen Monument Forest Dale Ironworks Kents Corner Theron Boyd Homestead Historic Bridges Lake Champlain Bridge Commemoration Underwater Preserves Archaeology Heritage Center Friends and Partners Seasonal Staff Opportunities Senator Justin Morrill The Senator Justin S. Morrill State Historic Site was the home of Justin Smith Morrill, the longest-serving member of Congress in the first 160 years of its history. During his tenure in Congress, Morrill advocated for higher education and reinforced a knowledge-based democracy. The Senator was recognized for sponsoring landmark legislation that helped establish public universities (Land Grant Acts) and for framing of the Fourteenth Amendment that granted equal protection and rights to freed slaves. Justin Morrill was essentially self-taught, amassing an impressive personal library and studying architecture on his own. He was responsible for the design of his family home in Strafford, Vermont. Constructed in 1851 and enlarged seven years later, the house is an outstanding example of the Gothic Revival style of architecture popularized by Andrew Jackson Downing and Alexander Jackson Davis in the early 19 th century. Senator Morrill used their architectural handbooks to design his dream house, adapting the forms and details to suit his own vision. Morrill also planned the surrounding gardens, studying the romantic landscape movement with its formal yet picturesque plantings. He selected only those plants that would survive the wintry Vermont climate and annually monitored their success again the harsh elements. Today, the homestead that Justin Morrill created in Strafford included a horse barn, carriage barn, ice house, blacksmith shop, and summer gazebo (no longer standing), which reflected Morrill’s diversified interests in farming, as well as the needs of 19th century rural living. The buildings were tightly grouped in a neat row along a farm road that lead back to a manmade ice pond on the hill at the back of the property. The pond was the source for an extensive water system that fed the house, barns, and gardens and was a source for harvesting ice. Additions and alterations to the property in 1901 by James Morrill, Justin’s only child, included the shuffle board court, hot house (razed 2016), cow barn, sheep barn, and relocated/joined the carriage barn and horse barn. In 1960, the property was recognized as a National Historic Landmark, the first such honorary designation in Vermont. The Senator Justin S. Morrill State Historic Site was created in 1969, when the property was conveyed to the State of Vermont by the Justin Smith Morrill Foundation, Inc. The 1851 house is dressed in furnishings from Morrill’s 1871 home that once stood at One Thomas Circle in Washington, D.C. In 2007, the horse barn relocated by James Morrill in 1901 was reconstructed in its original location to serve as an education center and library. Young historians, videographers, and photographers did remarkable work at the Justin Morrill State Historic Site during the 2020 Photo & Video Story Camp. The camp was sponsored by the Friends of the Morrill Homestead and managed by Lindsay and Scott McClure Miller of World Story Exchange. For similar programming sponsored by the Friends of the Morrill Homestead, please visit their website. Friends of Morrill Homestead Website VIEW videos created by campers during the 2020 Photo & Video Story Camp.

homepage_content: Visit The Franconia Heritage Museum 0 Franconia Heritage Museum FAHC Annual Meeting Thursday, November 13, 2025 Chef Joe’s Bistro The Franconia Area Heritage Council invites you to its annual meeting on Thursday, November 13, 2025 at Chef Joe’s Bistro in Franconia. We will meet in the downstairs dining room at 5:30 PM. This year’s event is free of charge, serving Chef Joe’s famous heavy hors d'oeuvres, with a cash bar available. Holiday Refreshments will be served! Please RSVP here with your name and how many... Is your Ancestor on this list? If so, they made a Signature Quilt Square between 1876-1895, and it is preserved and available for viewing at the Franconia Heritage Museum. We offer various opportunities for you to own a high resolution replica of this special piece of history. Inquire! FAHC Appoints Elizabeth Aiken to its Board of Directors The Franconia Area Heritage Council has appointed Elizabeth Aiken to their Board of Directors at its Annual Meeting, held at Chef Joe’s Bistro on Thursday, November 14, 2024. Liz currently resides in Phoenix, AZ where she serves the Phoenix Zoo as their Gift Planning Manager. A career philanthropic professional, Liz is an accomplished fundraising executive with extensive experience in major gift cultivation, solicitation and stewardship, Moves Management, budget and workplan development, and donor engagement. Prior to joining the Phoenix Zoo, she held executive positions with Child Crisis Arizona; the Sandra Day O’Connor College of Law, Arizona State University; Planned Parenthood Arizona; and the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America. Liz is joining the Heritage Council at an exciting time in our growth as we make investments in archival technology, maintenance of our ca. 1880 Franconia Heritage Museum, and climate control to the building to protect and preserve our ever-growing collection. Welcome aboard, Liz! Franconia Notch Documentary Narrated by Fritz Wetherbee

name: Morgantown History Museum
address: 175 Kirk St, Morgantown, WV 26505, USA
homepage_content: HOME | Morgantown History M top of page Explore your story at the Morgantown history museum ABOUT US ABOUT THE MORGANTOWN HISTORY MUSEUM In 2011, the Morgantown History Museum became the first city-sponsored museum in the county with a mission to collect, record, and preserve artifacts and information related to Monongalia County throughout its history and to share it with museum visitors. The current collection contains artifacts from prehistory to the present. The exhibition floor follows a timeline of permanent and rotating exhibits that feature historical events, individuals, and achievements. Permanent exhibits feature Don Knotts, a vintage printing shop, local glassware, pottery, musicians, and more. Admission to the museum is free. Group tours are available upon request. The museum is located in the annex of a former Morgantown Post Office located at 175 Kirk Street. Completed in 1931, the annex was a necessary expansion to the post office building that was completed in 1914. The post office and annex served the community until the 1970s, when a new post office was built nearby. Both the former post office and annex were placed on the National Register of Historic Places on March 28, 1979. SEEKING ARTIFACT DONATIONS We are currently looking for artifacts relating to Morgantown businesses that have been in existance for 10+ years. This can include historical artifacts from the business, photographs or any significant documents pertaining to the business. Email Us CONTACT CONTACT US MORGANTOWN HISTORY MUSEUM Wed - Fri: 11 a.m. - 5 p.m. ​​Sat - Sun: 12 p.m. - 6 p.m. The museum is closed on all major holidays Address: 175 Kirk Street, Morgantown, WV 26505 morgantownwvhistory@morgantownwv.gov Phone Number: 304-319-1800 First Name Last Name Email Subject Message Submit Thanks for submitting! bottom of page

name: Thomas Griswold House
address: 171 Boston St, Guilford, CT 06437, USA
homepage_content: Thomas Griswold House top of page The Thomas Griswold House Museum (1764) 171 Boston Street Guilford June - September Saturday 11-4 & Sunday 12-4 Admission is Free. The Thomas Griswold House is a classic New England saltbox dwelling standing on a commanding knoll along a picturesque stretch of the old Post Road in Guilford-now designated as a state scenic road. Thomas Griswold III built the house for two of his sons, John and Ezra, circa 1764, on land that had been in the Griswold family since Thomas Griswold II moved from Wethersfield in 1695. John Griswold, Jr. sold his interest in the property to his cousin George, who also inherited his father Ezra's portion. The house remained in the possession of descendants of George and his wife, Nancy Landon, until purchased by the Guilford Keeping Society in 1958. The Guilford Keeping Society has carried out two major restoration projects, one in 1974 and one in 1995. The house is now furnished in the style of the early nineteenth century, representing the period of George and Nancy Griswold's occupancy. Several items mentioned in George Griswold's inventory are still in the house, including a parlor mirror and a dressing table. One upstairs room is dedicated to temporary exhibits of items from the Society's collection, primarily nineteenth century clothing and Guilford photographs. homepage_content: Welcome to Norskedalen - Norskedalen Directions to Norskedalen Welcome to Norskedalen Norskedalen (which means the Norwegian Valley), is a nature and heritage center dedicated to preserving, interpreting and sharing the natural environment and cultural heritage of the area surrounding Coon Valley in southwest Wisconsin. Norskedalen has so much to offer in so many different ways, exploring the natural beauty, regional history and traditional cultural heritage of the region. Visit The Valley Whether you come to experience the natural beauty of the coulee region, the history of those who have lived here throughout time or the Norwegian heritage preserved in the buildings and artifacts, Norskedalen has something unique and very special to offer. Admission $10 per person 12 years and older | $5 per person 4-11 years old | $25 per household of 5 or less $ 6 per person for seniors 65 years and older | $ 6 for veterans and active military with ID Hours of Operation May – Oct M-Sa: 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Su: 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Please contact us for information on guided tours of the Homestead, and guided hikes on our trails. Nov – Apr M-Sa: 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Su: 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. This schedule may change due to weather or events. Please don’t hesitate to call to verify tour times before you travel. All members and visitors are asked to check in at the Thrune Visitors’ Center before enjoying our grounds. Thank you! Washington Auto Road | Adventures in Gorham, NH Skip to primary navigation Skip to content Skip to footer Pause Play Video Unmute Mute Book Now ROAD STATUS: Closed for the Season Mt. Washington SnowCoach Tour the Mt. Washington Auto Road in Winter From $ 79 Hour Glass 1.5 hours User 13+ , All Ages Mt. Washington SnowCoach Climb aboard the Mt. Washington SnowCoach for a truly unforgettable adventure to an extreme world! Book Now Learn More 2-Hour Guided Tour Featured Activity Hour Glass 2 hours User All Ages 2-Hour Guided Tour 2-Hour Guided Tours offer a unique opportunity to learn the true nature and history of Mount Washington. Book Now Learn More Drive Yourself From $ 36 Drive Yourself Driving the Auto Road is about a new experience at every turn, even if you’ve already driven it several times. Weather, foliage, views … they’re always changing and keep the trip exciting. Drive yourself and earn the famous “This Car Climbed Mount Washington” bumper sticker! Hours & Dates (opens in new window) Learn More AMERICA'S OLDEST MAN-MADE ATTRACTION! Constructed during the 1850s, the Mt. Washington Auto Road climbs from Route 16 in Pinkham Notch in New Hampshire to the highest peak in the Northeast at 6288 feet. The oldest man-made tourist attraction in the United States, which opened on August 8, 1861, to the summit, has been proudly family-owned and operated since 1906. We continue the heritage of guided tours on the mountain with experienced, informative drivers. Stewardship, history, and ecological information are prominent topics on the tours. If you choose, like so many families and individuals before you, you can take your own vehicle up the Auto Road to enjoy the weather, views, and summit activities at the Sherman Adams Building, which sits in the Mt. Washington State Park at the summit. At the base of the Auto Road, you will find our main lodge offering restrooms, a gift shop, a small snack cafe, and our sister company, Great Glen Trails . We offer lodging at the newest Glen House Hotel, which sits at the base of the Auto Road and offers stunning views for your overnight stay to enjoy the many offerings of the property in the summer or winter. We look forward to seeing you soon! DRIVE YOURSELF No reservations necessary GUIDED TOURS Book a reservation ATVs On The Auto Road SUNSET ON MT. WASHINGTON Lodging Renowned Events Bicknell's Thrush Tours Red Barn Museum PLAN YOUR VACATION TODAY 2-Hour Guided Tour Featured Activity Hour Glass 2 hours User All Ages 2-Hour Guided Tour 2-Hour Guided Tours offer a unique opportunity to learn the true nature and history of Mount Washington. Washington Discovery Tour 3-Hour Guided Tours offer a unique opportunity to learn the true nature, weather, and history of Mount Washington. Washington from the open-air seat of your ATV / UTV! Book Now Learn More Auto Road Summer Season Pass Great Value for Frequent Visitors From $ 125 Auto Road Summer Season Pass Whether you’re a hiker, photographer, birder—or just love having access to the tallest peak in the northeast—a season pass pays for itself in just a few drives! Book Now Learn More – Wildlife Kayaking From $ 115.00 Hour Glass 8 hours User 13+ – Wildlife Kayaking Great Glen Trails Outdoor Center Our trip is your gateway to river exploration in which we’ll show you a beautiful, quiet section of the Androscoggin River. Book Now Sunset Drives From $ 39 Hour Glass 2 hours User All Ages Sunset Drives Drive yourself to watch the sunset from the highest peak in the northeast! Book Now TAKE IN THE BREATHTAKING VIEWS OF MT. WASHINGTON WELL worth the time, energy & money! We took the Auto Tour (a large van) & were so glad we did....lane widths are just adequate, and there are no guardrails. Smelled a lot of hot brakes! But oh my! What phenomenal views! The maples were aflame with color! And Mt Washington is way above the surrounding mountains, so you see peak after peak below you, as you look to the horizon, plus a few lakes. Just beautiful. Is we're ever here again, we may take the courage train up. – Mary C. | Tripadvisor Trip to the Rock Pile Mt. Washington is a long time favorite of ours. We enjoy going up, not matter how the method. This time we took the coach. Kevin was a great tour guide!! He was funny, polite and great to listen to. The clouds and fall colors were wonderful. Way to many people, but have to share right. We can't wait to go again – Jay C. | Tripadvisor Exceeded Expectations Had a truly awesome ride up the mountain yesterday in a 61-year old Morgan. The road is steep, bendy, and narrow but stay calm and in low gear and you'll do just fine. The weather yesterday was perfect and visibility fantastic in all directions. Because of that the road was busy and my biggest problem was big SUVs and trucks slowing down as I was going up to squeeze past each other. It is a narrow road but the views are incredible. Highly recommended--but do check the weather at the summit first. – Jonathan K. | Tripadvisor Excellent Definitely the way to go, don’t drive yourself, this is much more relaxing and you can see the scenery. Just the right amount of time. You also will get more from the informative guides also. It was overcast and foggy when we started but we went through the clouds and it was mostly sunny and actually warmer with no wind at the top, not what we were expecting. Unusual as our guide said. Definitely recommend. – Daniel O. | Tripadvisor Do not pass this up! Going to the top of Mount Washington was the highlight of our trip. It’s amazing to see the forest change as you gain elevation and it’s truly like another world at the top. We debated driving versus the guided tour. I’m very thankful we did this. The price is reasonable and the guide was great. More importantly it made me thankful I did not attempt to drive it myself. You will learn a lot from others mistakes and save your brakes. – Michelle D. | Tripadvisor Awesome, amazing! This was an amazing experience that I had to live. The views are espectacular. I’m not going to lie, going up there was a rush of adrenaline. I was scared but excited too. Kevin was our tour guide and he was so wonderful. Very kind, he was telling us all about the Mountains, trail tracks and everything. Loved this! – Marleny H. | Tripadvisor Link Gallery DONATE TODAY IN SUPPORT OF THE MT. WASHINGTON OBSERVATORY Link Gallery The Mount Washington Observatory is a private, nonprofit, member-supported institution with a mission to advance understanding of the natural systems that create Earth’s weather and climate. It serves this mission by maintaining a weather station on the summit of Mount Washington, performing weather and climate research, conducting innovative science education programs, and interpreting the heritage of the Mount Washington region. Fortunately, it still can be reproduced. Please help make this possible. Contribute to Parlor Carpet Artifact Preservation General Fund $25.00 $50.00 $75.00 $100.00 $250.00 $500.00 Custom Amount Please enter an amount $ One-Time Donation Weekly Donation Monthly Donation Support us by covering the fees we have to pay 3% Cover the Fee Donate Donate Sauk County Historical Society Please consider becoming a member or providing a donation to the Sauk County Historical Society. Museum The Van Orden Mansion has served as the home of the Sauk County Historical Museum since 1939. Finished in 1904, the mansion contains over one hundred years of artifacts donated to the society. Original features include woodwork, wall coverings, light fixtures, carpets and some of the family's furniture. Location: 531 4th Ave., Baraboo, WI When: May through October - Wednesday through Saturday afternoons from 12 to 4 pm. Admission: Free Learn more about the Van Orden Mansion Become a Member Business membership History Center In December of 2006, the Sauk County Historical Society acquired the historic Island Woolen Mill office building from the city of Baraboo for $1. Fundraising and renovations then went hand in hand until the building was renovated and restored for use as the Sauk County History Center opening in 2013. The building now houses the offices, archives and research center for the historical society. Location: 900 2nd Ave., Baraboo, WI Open: Wed - Fri noon to 4 p.m. / Saturdays by appointment. Please call 608-356-1001 to schedule a Saturday research time. Learn More about the History Center

homepage_content:
Lieu historique national Louis-S.-St-Laurent Passer au contenu principal Passer à « Au sujet du gouvernement » Lieu historique national Louis-S.-St-Laurent Situé à Compton dans les Cantons-de-l'Est, à 20 kilomètres de Sherbrooke, le lieu historique national Louis-S.-St-Laurent rappelle la vie et l'œuvre de l'ancien premier ministre du Canada. Visitez sa maison natale et le magasin général de son père, et tombez sous le charme du début du 20 e siècle. Parcourez l’histoire singulière d'un homme réputé pour son intégrité et laissez-vous envoûter par les attraits du village champêtre qui l'a vu grandir. Informations utiles Le lieu historique national Louis-S.-St-Laurent est temporairement fermé au grand public pour la saison et rouvrira au printemps 2026. D’ici là, le site accueille les groupes (scolaires, socioculturels, etc.) de juin à septembre, sur réservation seulement. Voyez les détails . Ateliers scolaires virtuels Vous travaillez dans l'enseignement? Découvrez nos ateliers scolaires virtuels conçus pour les élèves du primaire et du secondaire, et présentés gratuitement par Parcs Canada et École en réseau. Gloriette au jardin Un pavillon a récemment vu le jour dans la cour arrière. Découvrez-en plus sur ce projet. Retour dans le temps Familiarisez-vous avec l'histoire de cet ancien premier ministre du Canada et de sa famille. Voyez les détails . #LouisStLaurent #ParcsCanada Facebook Twitter YouTube Instagram D'autres lieux à découvrir avec Parcs Canada Lieu historique national du Fort-Chambly À une trentaine de kilomètres au sud-est de Montréal, s’élève fièrement le fort Chambly au pied des rapides du Richelieu. Érigée en 1711 pour défendre la colonie, cette fortification de pierre a été précédée par trois forts en bois. Lieu historique national du Canal-de-Chambly À 20 km de Montréal, une véritable oasis attend les amateurs de vélos et de plein air : le site historique du canal de Chambly. Observez les écluses et les ponts livrer passage aux plaisanciers, et en août, admirez les montgolfières se faufiler entre les nuages. Magique. Lieu historique national du Fort-Lennox Construit sur l'île aux Noix entre 1759 et 1760, le fort Lennox a rouvert ses portes après d’importants travaux de réfection. Ce lieu mythique fut au cœur de la défense des Français face à l'invasion des Britanniques par la rivière Richelieu et l'escapade en traversier pour s'y rendre vaut à elle seule une visite. Date de modification : 2025-09-10

name: Motorama Auto Museum
address: 181705 Stradale Ln, Aniwa, WI 54408, USA
homepage_content: Motorama Auto Museum - You Have to See it to Believe it! Dear Motorama Family Oct 13TH UPDATE: So very many people to thank for all the help and support you all have given to us. Storm damage will always be with us but we believe the grounds are better than ever. Thank-you. This year’s Halloween Party is quickly approaching. It is the last day of the season for Motorama. Come join us for spooky fun! WISCONSIN’S LARGEST Over 500 Vehicles on Display! FREE ADMISSION FOR KIDS UNDER 16 Visit us from May through October, Wednesday to Saturday, 9 am to 5 pm (soft close at 4 pm). Admission is $10 for adults, while kids 15 and under enjoy free entry. Immerse yourself in the world of automobiles without breaking the bank – making it a perfect family outing. Discover the joy of history and innovation! Indoor and Outdoor Exhibits Explore a captivating mix of indoor and outdoor exhibits. Engage with themed displays such as the Main Museum, Bike Barn, Old Car Boneyard, Motor Pool, Race Car Room, and Ralph's Quality Covairs. Whether you prefer the nostalgia of classic cars or the excitement of race cars, our displays promise an immersive journey through automotive history. Enjoy the best of both worlds – step inside and venture outdoors to witness the evolution of iconic vehicles. Alfa Heaven Motorsports Bar & Banquet Hall Indulge in a unique experience at Motorama with the Alfa Heaven Motorsports Bar and Banquet Hall. Recharge with a drink at our Motorsports Bar, surrounded by the buzz of automotive passion. Plan your special events in our versatile Banquet Hall, offering a distinctive setting for celebrations. Elevate your visit with the perfect blend of camaraderie and hospitality. Cheers to unforgettable moments! Event Grounds with RV Sites Surrounding the Museum are the expansive Events Grounds, operated by Alfa Heaven, Inc., where automotive excitement meets outdoor leisure. When you are here for an event, the grounds offer a delightful blend of automotive charm and serene surroundings. Immerse yourself in the full Motorama experience! Looking for the perfect place to hold your next gathering? Look no further. Unwind amidst nature with our Campground featuring RV sites and full laundry, restrooms, and hot showers, providing a perfect retreat for enthusiasts. This is the place to make your special occasion happen. YOU HAVE TO SEE IT TO BELIEVE IT! Motorama Auto Museum is located in a beautiful, private, forested area with the Eau Claire River running through the property. Experience the rich tapestry of twentieth-century automobiles, showcasing rare and unique vehicles from around the globe. With themed displays, captivating exhibits, and knowledgeable guides, our museum offers an unforgettable exploration of the evolution, engineering, and aesthetics of iconic automobiles. Discover the stories that shaped automotive history within it’s walls Learn More AS SEEN ON UPCOMING FEATURED EVENTS * UPCOMING FEATURED EVENTS * UPCOMING FEATURED EVENTS * 8/14-15/2026 CENTRAL WISCONSIN MILITARY AND 4x4 SHOW Join us for Wisconsin's largest military show, now featuring the Wisconsin 4×4 Show and Jeep showcase! Experience our signature vehicle displays, swap meet, and awards, plus an exciting expansion welcoming Wisconsin's Off-Road and 4×4 community to the Motorama Event Grounds. Don't miss our charity auction and the chance to be part of this incredible combined event! Visit the Event Page for details. Halloween Party! October 31 - 7PM Costumes encouraged, Pot Luck, Spooky Drag Show, Car bonfire, costume contest and dancing! Enjoy something a little bit different! Motorama Auto Museum took the spotlight in a featured episode of "Wisconsin Life" on PBS the day after Christmas in 2019. Thousands of folks at home got to experience the charm and stories of our little museum, showcasing the passion and history behind our collection. DID YOU KNOW? Get in touch. name: Fort McClary State Historic Site
address: Pepperrell Rd, Kittery Point, ME 03905, USA
homepage_content: State Parks and Public Lands: Maine ACF - Search Results Skip Maine state header navigation Home Skip to top navigation Skip to side navigation Skip to content Skip to footer Home → Bureaus & Programs → Bureau of Parks and Lands → Find Parks & Lands → Park Details Fort McClary State Historic Site Maine Trail Finder Group picnic shelter Picnic area Description Stay informed. Check the Bureau's safety page. Open 10:00 a.m. to sunset daily from Memorial Day to Columbus Day unless otherwise posted at the gate. Fee charged. Visitors may continue to enjoy the park during the off season by parking outside the gate and walking in during these same hours. Please be aware that facilities are closed during the off season. For more than 275 years, a fort has stood to protect the approaches to the Piscataqua River at the southern gateway to Kittery, Maine. The most recent of these is Fort McClary, named for New Hampshire native Major Andrew McClary who died at the Revolutionary War's Battle of Bunker Hill. Fort McClary stands today as one of the state's most important historic forts that dramatically preserves evidence of military history and changes in military architecture and technology. The buildings presently on the site represent several different periods of construction as the fort was upgraded and modified to meet the area's defensive needs. The site was manned during five wars: The Revolutionary War, War of 1812, Civil War, Spanish-American War, and World War I. Like most other Maine forts, it saw little conflict. If you are interested in learning about geology around the state, check out the Maine Geological Survey Searchable Database. homepage_content: Military Veterans Museum – Honoring our Nation’s military history through education and preservation Skip to content Military Veterans Museum & Welcome to the Education Center Honoring our Nation’s military history through education and preservation Have you recently visited our Museum? Click here and fill out a Google review! Click Here to Learn About Our Expansion Plans! Our Story Our organization began with a shared dream of 5 WWII veterans. This group of men dreamed of the day there would be a museum in the East-Central part of Wisconsin dedicated to telling the stories of our Honored Veterans. Learn More LATEST UPDATES AND NEWS Get in the know Of everything going on with MVMEC! Tickets for the 2026 52-Week Sportsman’s Raffle are In! They can be purchased at the museum Fridays through Sundays 10-5. Would you like to help us sell tickets, email us at info@mvmec.org. See poster at left for details. We are going back to our Summer Hours! 10AM to 5PM Friday, Saturday and Sunday. We also have a YouTube Channel! It includes Veterans stories and our Artifact Minutes. Check it out here ! Be sure to “like”, subscribe, and hit the bell so you receive notifications of new videos! MVMEC has just published a new book telling the stories of its history and of several of the artifacts on display. It is available @ Amazon through the link below and is also available in our gift shop. Click Here to see it on Amazon. Many of our visitors ask what happened to the T34-85 Tank we used to have on display. We have an article on the tank on page 5 of our Winter 2022 Newsletter. Click here to see the Newsletter. And, as always, Private Tours are available year round. Call Stu Tribbey (920) 379-1180 or tribbey70@gmail.com to schedule a visit. Our Motor Pool area can be set up with tables and chairs for group meetings or other events like birthday parties. Interested? Contact Stu Tribbey at the above phone number or email. member and visitor comments Thomas Comens I was impressed by all the military artifacts and information in the building. The volunteers who greeted us were very friendly. And more than willing to answer questions. I recommend this place to anyone interested in military history. I’ve already decided this is one place I will be going back to. Stephanie Heinritz Spent a few hours at the Military Veterans Museum & Education Center this Memorial Day with Livi. We received an awesome tour with another family from Ron, and were even able to see a few of the trucks, jeeps etc being driven and parked by veterans and volunteers between parades. Carri Jones Someone recommended this museum while we would be in Oshkosh to visit the EAA museum. From the outside, it may not appear to be much, but WOW, were we surprised! Stu greeted us and gave us an overview of what was where in the museum, and then we were off to explore. There’s uniforms and artifacts from different eras, excellent videos, but the best is the giant garage with MANY military vehicles. There are quite a few you can get in to, sit in, pretend, etc. Very kid friendly. Uniforms they can wear while in the museum. Everyone was VERY friendly. When we went, it was only open Fri-Sun. Admission is free, but donations accepted. Don’t sleep on it – highly recommend! Debbie Krajnovich I thought it was great and very educational. I did not realize that there was going to be somebody explaining every exhibit on display which was kind of neat otherwise we would have just walked past the exhibits and not realized exactly anything about what went on at period of time. Brittany There was a lot more here than I thought. The staff are very knowledgeable and friendly. The amount of vehicles they have that you can see up close and personal and even the weapons was very impressive. Mandy Petri This is an amazing place to learn about all the wars. It’s so important to keep this knowledge alive. Ted was so incredibly informative and loved that our kids came along. He made us all feel very welcome

Tickets can be purchased online here: Online Ticket Reservations VISIT See the splendor of Pabst Mansion on a tour! SHOP Check out our PBR and Pabst Mansion goods! CONTRIBUTE Contribute to the Pabst Mansion. Mission Statement: Pabst Mansion, Inc. preserves, shares, and interprets an iconic Milwaukee home that serves as a testament to the Gilded Age. Through immersive tours, educational opportunities, and programming, Pabst Mansion, Inc. brings visitors back in time to help understand the present, sharing the story of brewing, architecture, art, and culture through the lens of the Pabst family and its impact on Milwaukee. Vision Statement: Pabst Mansion, Inc. seeks to position the Pabst Mansion as the foremost example of a preserved 1890s Gilded Age Mansion in the Midwest, and across the country. We strive to restore, preserve, celebrate and share an immersive German Milwaukee experience that welcomes visitors to experience the Pabst Mansion as it was imagined, built and enjoyed by the Pabst family through tours, education programs, and events. name: Elmbrook Historical Society
address: 1075 Pilgrim Pkwy, Brookfield, WI 53005, USA
homepage_content: Elmbrook Historical Society Dousman Stagecoach Inn Museum Exhibits Gardens Photo Opportunity Tours Direction/Links Special Events Father's Day at the Inn 1860's Afternoon Teas Christmas at the Inn Annual Meeting Mission Statement The Elmbrook Historical Society is a non-profit educational organization. The mission of this organization shall be the collection, preservation and dissemination of materials and information relating to the history of the City of Brookfield, the Village of Elm Grove, the Town of Brookfield and the County of Waukesha. Sign up Now! Join the Elmbrook Historical Society ! Help preserve the history of Brookfield and Elm Grove for generations to come!! Membership Application Elmbrook Historical Society Board Meeting Schedule Society's Board of Directors meet at 7:00 pm City of Brookfield Brookfield Park & Senior Center - East Meeting Room 2000 N Calhoun Road Brookfield, WI 53005 on the following dates: *February 17. 2025 *April 21, 2025 *June 17, 2024 *August 18, 2025 *October 20, 2025 *December 15, 2025 The Elmbrook Historical Society Founded in 1977, the Elmbrook Historical Society is an affiliate of the Wisconsin Historical Society. It currently has over 175 members who care deeply about preserving the history of Brookfield and Elm Grove and its historic buildings. The Dousman Stagecoach Inn Museum is its main project. Dousman Stagecoach Inn Museum An active organization, the Elmbrook Historical Society hosts a number of activities that are open to the public. These include: Lectures on a variety of historic topics that are held on a Monday evening during the months of March, September and November at the Brookfield Public Library Docent led tours of the historic Dousman Stagecoach Inn Museum, the only building in Brookfield that is listed on the National Register of Historic Places Walking tours of local historic interest Special fund raising events such as: Afternoon Teas Christmas at the Inn Annual Meeting In addition, our members: Maintain the Dousman Stagecoach Inn Museum , a stately Greek Revival Inn built in 1843, its gardens and its outbuildings Collect and display artifacts at the Dousman Stagecoach Inn Museum reflecting the period of 1840's to 1880's Archive documents and record information of historical interest from area residents Work to preserve buildings of historic interest in Brookfield and Elm Grove Community Walkway Help us preserve our local history by purchasing an engraved brick to show you have walked this way. These bricks make wonderful gifts to mark a special occasion or honor someone. All proceeds from your support of this Community Walkway will help fund the historical society in our preservation efforts, events and education. Click here for details and to download a form In these and many other ways, the Elmbrook Historical Society works to preserve the history of Brookfield and Elm Grove for generations to come.
